NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Wages – TR ordinary seaman (MS. #18 on arrival crew list) is not being paid according applicable CBA (Singapore Maritime officers union (SMOU) OS rank. To be rectified and paid retroactively since joining date 17/03/2024.

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
Vessel staff had just completed maintenance of Main Engine Unit No 1. While carrying out Engine 
room inspection inspector noticed traces of oil near the Main Engine fuel pump. 
Root Cause: 
Vessel had just completed ME Unit Overhaul and inadvertently missed out to clean the area properly 
leading to have oil traces near fuel pump.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
Corrective Action: 
Traces of oil has been cleaned from the fuel pump no.1 and also a through round of engine room was 
taken to ensure that no other oil traces are there in Engine room machinery.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: A small oil leak was found on the main engine during the inspection
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
Preventive Measures: 
Tanking a positive note of this observation, Technical superintendent held telcon briefing with vessel 
SMT to emphasize the need for proper housekeeping and maintaining a safe working environment 
during all work processes. After completion of Machinery maintenance in Engine room , area should 
be thoroughly cleaned and Engine room should be kept in the good housekeeping standard. 
This observation shall be shares with all fleet vessels for knowledge & experience sharing and to 
highlight the importance of proper housekeeping at all times.
YARD: Shina SB Shipyard CO@Tongyoung South Korea

NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: NIL

NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Statement of compliance for Fuel Oil consumption reporting and CII not retained Onboard.

AREA_OF_CONCERN:
The solenoid valves of sample point distribution system of the fixed gas detection system
must be subject to periodical overhauling during the annual shore calibration by competent
serviceThe effectiveness of corrective and preventive actions should be verified during the vessel
inspections by the company Superintendents and Auditors technicians.
CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
Upon investigation and troubleshooting it was found that, the solenoid valve in the system
serving the purpose for drawing tank cleaning operation room atmosphere samples and
delivering them to the sensing unit was not fully operational due to presence of some stains
and foreign particles inside the valve.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
While testing fixed Gas Detection System during PSC inspection, Tank Cleaning Operations
Room sample point (port side) testing failed. After applying span calibration gas (n-Butane
50% LEL) to sample point, no gas reached system sensor and so no alarm was activated on the
panel.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Gas detection system test failed
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
Troubleshooting was carried out by the vessel staff. The defective solenoid valve was
dismounted, inspected, cleaned, and mounted back. The system was tested by applying span
gas to the sample points in Tank Cleaning Operations Room. The span gas reached the system
sensor and alarms were activated.
Attached is the report of the corrective action taken by the vessel staff.

AREA_OF_CONCERN: Ch II/Company Documents - (Safety management manuals and procedures)
CAUSE_ANALYSIS: The concerned engine rating in this case had wrongly ticked understanding of Oil record book/filling procedures not applicable to his rank. When he was questioned by the PSCO regarding understanding of the Oil Record Book he got nervous and subsequently failed to answer the questions. As the crew had wrongly ticked in his familiarization booklet for task familiarization that does not fall under his job profile (Oil Record Book) and subsequently as he could not answer question related to Oil Record Book, the PSCO noted that the effectiveness of the ISM system needs to be verified by conducting an internal audit within 90 days.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Deficiency marked ISM are objective evidence of the ISM system poor application and /or system failure. Internal audit by the management to be done within 90 days.
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION: The company appointed Auditor completed the Internal Audit on board the vessel at Vancouver on 17th May 2022. During the audit process, all aspects of the ISM system was covered including crew safety familiarization. The internal auditor briefed the Senior management regarding proper filling up of the SF-10 Safety familiarization booklet and proper familiarization of the crew with respect to the tasks mentioned in the SF-10 Safety familiarization booklet. A Meeting with all onboard crew was also carried on board by the auditor emphasizing the need for the crew on board to get familiar with all items mentioned in the safety familiarization booklet and Job specific task.

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
➢ Inadequate review of seafarer’s documents prior joining the vessel
➢ Inadequate compliance to STCW/CI/R9 - certificate should be signed by seafarer and medical practitioner.
➢ Inadequate review by Manning Company, Manager & Master to ensure crew certificates are duly signed.
➢ Failure of crew to read and sign personal documents upon receipt.

NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Crew certificates/medical certificate / five medical certificates for service at sea found without seafarers signature
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
➢ Company to verify that fleet vessels hold valid seafarer certificates (e.g., Employment agreement, Medical cert., CoCs, COE/ROA as applicable, etc.) and ensure they are signed by seafarers prior joining the vessel
➢ Ship staff to thoroughly review crew documents and update the form AD-05 Crew Certificate Checklist.
➢ Fleet Alert to be circulated to managed vessels for awareness

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
Immediate Cause:
During the vessel's passage to China, it encountered rough weather. The bridge window
wipers were in continuous use under adverse conditions, leading to a mechanical failure
in the motor of one wiper, rendering it inoperable.
Root Cause:
1. Mechanical wear and tear: Prolonged operation in adverse conditions placed
excessive strain on the wiper motor, leading to its failure.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
Corrective Actions:
1. Replaced the faulty wiper motor with a new unit to restore full functionality.
2. Inspected all other bridge window wipers to confirm they are fully operational and
in good working condition.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: One window wiper on the bridge is faculty and cannot operate normally
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
Preventive Actions:
1. Stocked adequate spare parts, including motors and wiper blades, for timely
repairs to minimize operational delays.
2. Conducted crew training on the importance of:
o Monitoring the operational condition of bridge equipment during adverse
weather.
o Reporting any abnormalities immediately to prevent further damage.3. Shared this observation fleetwide to:
o Increase awareness of potential equipment failures under heavy usage
conditions.
YARD: Shina SB Shipyard CO@Tongyoung South Korea

Direct Cause: Crew were not familiar with emergency towing system.
Indirect Cause:
➢ Procedures were not discussed on board with the crew hence they are not aware of the location of Emergency Towing Tools & Equipment.
➢ Emergency towing arrangement drill was not performed within the interval of 6 months as per Drill Planner SF-19.
Root Cause:
➢ Inadequate compliance with the Contingency Manual Chapter 5.21 Emergency Towing and Salvage.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN: ➢ Master carried out training and familiarization on Emergency Towing Arrangement and Procedures as per Emergency Towing Booklet and Contingency Manual chapter 5.21 Emergency Towing and Salvage

➢ Master to ensure all crew onboard are aware of Emergency Towing Booklet and Contingency Manual chapter 5.21 Emergency Towing and Salvage and contingency checklist “CN-20”

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
Overview:
During a USCG Port State Control (PSC) inspection, it was observed that the ventilation fan for the
bosun store tripped immediately when started. Upon investigation, seawater ingress was identified
as the cause, leading to motor overload and seizure of the forward and aft bearings.
Cause Analysis:
Immediate/Direct Cause:
• Seawater ingress into the bosun store ventilation fan caused the fan motor to trip due to
overload.Root Cause:
o Ingress of Sea water due to keeping the ventilator not shut completely during nonconducive weather condition.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
Corrective Action:
1. Overhauling the Ventilation Fan:
o The crew carried out an overhaul of the ventilator fan.
o The motor was found to have seawater ingress, and both the forward and aft bearings
were seized.
2. Repairs Conducted:
o Motor rotor bearings were replaced.
o Stator windings were cleaned using fresh water to remove salt deposits and
subsequently treated with Electrosolve.
3. Testing and Restoration:
o After reassembly, the ventilation fan was tested and found to be in proper working
condition.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: The ventilation in bosun store tripped immediately upon being energized.
PSC_CATEGORY: Working and Living Conditions - Working Conditions
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
Preventive Action:
1. Crew Awareness and Pre-Arrival Checks:
o The vessel’s superintendent conducted a briefing for senior management onboard,
emphasizing the importance of testing all ventilator fans prior to port arrival and
emphasise to follow the PMS thoroughly .
2. Ships staff has been briefed to ensure that ventilation fans are fully shut while space is not
occupied during the Non conducive weather condition to avoid ingress of the sea water .
3. Fleet-Wide Communication:
o The observation was shared with the entire fleet to stress the importance of rigorous
pre-arrival equipment testing and maintenance practices.
YARD: Shina SB Shipyard CO@Tongyoung South Korea

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
The vessel was loaded with various parcels of soyabean oil and canola oil and the steam system was used to maintain the required cargo temperature. During the inspection, the PSCO checked the MARPOL shipping document, heating log, and cargo temperatures. Cargo temperatures were maintained in accordance with the discharge temperature requirements specified in the MARPOL shipping document. During the deck round, the inspector checked the deck condition, pipelines, and associated fittings. The deck fittings and pipelines were found to be in good condition, as noted by the PSCO. However, the inspector observed a minor water leakage on the welding seam of one of the branch line sections of the steam inlet line located near the 5W/S cargo tanks and hence raised this as a deficiency. We confirm at the time of inspection, the vessel was not discharging cargo from the 5W/S cargo tanks.
The vessel was carrying 5 parcels of soybean oil and 3 parcels of canola oil to be discharged at various ports. At the time of inspection, the vessel was discharging all 3 parcels of canola oil. After arrival at the berth, the officer in charge switched the cargo heating from the canola oil to the next set of tanks 5P and 5S to be discharged at the next port. Prior to changing over the tanks, the deck crew inadvertently missed draining the steam line of 5P and 5S. This oversight led to steam hammering in the branch line and resulted in a minor puncture of the line. Upon noticing this issue, the deck crew closed the main line and informed the chief officer and the master.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN: The vessel is equipped with 20 cargo tanks, each fitted with steam coils. Individual steam manifolds are provided for each cargo tank. Maintenance of steam lines and branch valves is included in the company's planned maintenance system and is an ongoing process. The main steam line, branch lines, and steam coils were pressure tested up to 7.0 bar, prior to the loading of cargo.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Cargo operations including equipment / Cargo transfer – Tankers / Main Deck, Steam Pipeline, Leaking.
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
Immediately after the vessel departure from port, the leaking pipe section was removed and permanent repairs on the welding seam of the branch lines was completed . After the repair, the entire main steam line was pressure tested to 7.0 bar and no leaks were found.
Master has confirmed the entire steam line is free from any leaks.

Following the inspection, the marine superintendent briefed all ship’s staff on the following points to prevent recurrence in the future:
- Always gradually heat up the steam line by opening the warming-up steam valve before starting.
- Inspect steam lines for any loose or hanging sections, loose fasteners, loose clamps, and blanking of line sections that are not in use before opening the steam.
- Drain accumulated condensate water from the line after use to avoid rapid condensation during the next use.
The deficiency has also been communicated to all fleet vessels to increase awareness and prevent recurrence

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
2. Identification of root cause:
During his round in the Engine Room the PSCO noted that there was an unauthorized electrical
Installation on the ceiling outside the entrance of the Engine control room above man height
reach. He Also noted that electrical connection on few of the machinery in the engine room were
not properly secured and hence noted it as a deficiency Code 40 ac. Upon Further investigation it
was noted that connection to the purifier motors, Sewage treatments plant sensors, Boiler
Junction Box, Light in emergency diesel space electrical putty was worn out and missed out to be
renewed by the concerned ship staff.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
The observation is regarding few machineries and lighting in engine room inadequately insulated.
The company has clear guidance for the care and maintenance of all electrical equipment’s on board
including light fittings. All machinery, electrical connection and lighting on deck and engine room are
to be properly insulated with a proper connector and suitable Gland Packing. No Unauthorized
connections are allowed in Accommodation, Deck or Machinery space.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY:
PSCO observed an authorized electrical installation in the form of a surge protector spliced into a light fixture and zip tied to a cable run outside of the CO2 room. Additionally, PSCO observed inadequately insulated electrical connections in the following locations:
-	Both FO purifier electric motors.
-	Both LO purifier electric motors.
-	Sewage treatment plant level sensor.
-	Boiler burner junction box
-	Light in emergency diesel generator space.
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
3. Correction of the finding 
On being pointed out by the inspector after following proper company Lock/out tag out
procedures the unauthorized electrical installation outside the entrance of the engine control
room was removed. Also, the electrical connections to both the LO purifiers, Both FO purifiers,
Sewage treatment plant sensor Box, Boiler Junction Box, Emergency generator light was
tightened, and electrical putty renewed. Class attended the vessel at Barcelona on 14th May-24
and verified closure of the deficiency. USCG were notified regarding class attendance and
verification by class. USCG has confirmed that the deficiency has been closed out in their system
4. Corrective/Preventive action based on the root cause
The superintendent carried out a briefing of the master and senior officer re-emphasizing the
importance of properly securing all electrical connection on deck and accommodation and engine
room. All Electrical equipment’s to have proper connectors. The Electrical putty on the electrical
connection to be periodically checked for wear and tear and to be immediately renewed.
5. What is the plan to monitor the effectiveness of the corrective/preventive actions?
1.All electrical connection of deck, Accommodation and Engine room was cross checked for signs
of damage/being worn out. Master has confirmed that the connection is noted to be in good
order
2.Verification of condition of the electrical connection will be carried out during Internal
audits/Vessel inspection to confirm compliance with company procedure.
3. The observation has been sent to all vessels in the fleet to avoid recurrence.

from the previous management, leading to their absence onboard. Master did not verify the 
presence of these documents
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
The missing EPIRB certificate for the 5-yearly SBM was acknowledged. The GMDSS Survey 
checklist, Section 240 J, indicated that the 5-yearly service was due in December 2025. We 
have contacted previous manager and 5 yearly SBM certificate was obtained. The last 5 Yearly
service was done on 31-Dec-2020. Please find the attached certificate.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Certificate for 5 yearly SBM of EPIRB could not be furnished. Certificate from competent person/organisation for 5 yearly load test of lifting appliances could not be furnished. EEXI technical file could not be furnished.
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
1. The missing EPIRB certificate for the 5-yearly SBM was acknowledged. The GMDSS Survey 
checklist, Section 240 J, indicated that the 5-yearly service was due in December 2025. We 
have contacted previous manager and 5 yearly SBM certificate was obtained. The last 5 Yearly
service was done on 31-Dec-2020. Please find the attached certificate.
2. The certificate from a competent person/organization for the 5-yearly load test of lifting 
appliances was initially unavailable. However, the certificate was subsequently acquired from the Class website. This certificate was presented to the PSC Inspector, leading to the closure 
of the observation.
3. The EEXI Technical file was initially missing. Nonetheless, the office later provided the EEXI 
technical file, Statement, and relevant communication pertaining to EMS-Circular-006-
2022/EEXI/CII/SEEMP III/Upcoming regulations. This information was promptly shared with 
the PSC Inspector, resulting in the observation being closed prior to departure.
To mitigate the likelihood of similar incidents in the future:
1. A comprehensive handover procedure has been reviewed during management transitions, 
ensuring the complete transfer of all certificates and documentation to the new 
management.
2. The checklist has been reviewed to systematically verify the presence of essential certificates 
and documents during the vessel takeover process.
3. The details of this observation and the corresponding actions taken have been communicated 
to all fleet vessels to enhance awareness and adherence.
By implementing these measures, we are committed to maintaining the integrity of our 
documentation, promoting compliance, and enhancing operational effectiveness across our fleet.
The Sikka PSC office was informed about the closure of this observation via email, along with 
supporting evidence. On 14-Sept-2023, Sikka PSC confirmed that the closure of Deficiency has been 
updated on the database and Updated Form B sent to the vessel

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
"""Direct Cause:
➢
Failure to identify that the escape route in the steering gear room was not marked with an IMO symbol.
Indirect Cause:
➢
PMS was insufficiently carried out.
-
Last routine inspection for ER Emergency Escape (Job Code 16710) was conducted by PIC on 27 Oct 2023. Although job was completed within the PMS schedule, this was not done properly. Records show that safety signs were checked and found in order, however, the emergency escape route in the steering gear room was not marked with the required IMO symbol.

Root Cause
Inadequate compliance with Health and Safety Manual Chapter 13C Safe Operational Practices – Markings of Escape Routes – 13C.2.

Inadequate compliance with Ship Management Manual Chapter 7 Responsibilities of Shipboard Personnel – 7.4."""	""".
Master briefed the PIC regarding compliance with the required IMO symbols for all escape routes and to ensure that they are clearly posted.
.
All emergency exits in the vessel were checked if proper markings and IMO symbols were in order.

.
A Fleet Alert is to be circulated to all vessels and must be discussed with all crew to avoid any recurrence of said PSC observation.
.
Adherence to company procedures regarding Emergency Exits within the vessel.
-
Health and Safety Manual Ch. 13C Safe Operational Practices – Markings of Escape Routes, Anti-slip, and Fall Hazards – 13C.2.
-
Ship Management Manual Ch. 7 Responsibilities of Shipboard Personnel – 7.4.
.
Vessels to check that all escape routes are properly marked with the appropriate IMO symbols and that these markings are in good order.
.
Persons in charge of all safety and lifesaving-related information posted within the vessel are to be briefed regarding their responsibility as per SMS and PMS."""
"""Direct Cause:
.
Failure to identify that heat insulation laggings were not installed in the boiler exhaust flange.
Indirect Cause:
.
Failure to identify hazards. The potential hazard of an exposed boiler exhaust flange was not identified.
.
Inadequate routine inspection in the engine room. No engine crew was able to report any missing insulation laggings in engine room hot spots.
Root Cause:
.
Failure in implementation of previous preventive actions, which were communicated to the vessel. Instances of lagging issues had been observed in other vessels during PSC inspections in the past, prompting the sharing of preventive measures across the fleet to prevent the recurrence of such PSC observations.
.
Inadequate compliance with Technical Manual Chapter 1.7 General – Safe Working Practices, item no. 7."""	""".
A Fleet Alert is to be circulated to all vessels and must be discussed with all crew to avoid any recurrence of said PSC observation.
.
Adherence to Technical Manual Chapter 1.7 General – Safe Working Practices and discuss with all engine officers and crew.
.
Superintendents to verify compliance during ship visits, VIR or internal audit.
.
To reinforce the adherence to preventive measures stated in the company instructions, a discussion emphasizing the significance of the implementation of the established preventive actions must be done at the next Monthly Safety Committee meeting.
.
Office to emphasize this recurring PSC observation to all engine officers and crew attending the pre-joining briefing during the discussion related to the latest incidents onboard and recent company instructions shared to the fleet."""

condition.

those on Generator (G/E) Fuel Oil (F.O) Feed Pump Rotary No. 2.Ensure that PMS procedures include clear guidelines
for inspection, maintenance, and renewal of shaft seals.
b. Provide training to relevant crew members on PMS procedures for shaft seals, emphasizing the importance of
adherence to inspection and maintenance schedules.
c. Fleet alert shared with all fleet vessels regarding the deficiency to ensure deficiency does not exist on other vessels.

AREA_OF_CONCERN: Ch II/Company Documents - (Safety management manuals and procedures)
CAUSE_ANALYSIS: Onboard investigation revealed that various IMO signs peeled off due to hot areas/surfaces in engine room. Even after this was pointed out during routine weekly inspection (in accordance with Company Procedures) by the Master/CE, the responsible Officer missed to replace the IMO directional signs clear on various locations in Engine room.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN: Master instructed the Responsible officer to immediately put the defective / missing IMO directional and exit signs on the missing surfaces.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY:
No IMO signage / marking found on escape door on emergency steering gear room and no IMO
directional signs inside steering gear room.
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION: Master immediately instructed responsible officer to have a thorough check missing IMO signs in the areas in Engine room. Upon completion of above checks, all areas were updated with various IMO signs and visible in all directional locations.A Safety meeting carried out onboard with all the crew and discussed the importance of the various IMO sign onboard and where location has been properly posted. All crew were encouraged to inform the Officers in-charge once they have noticed any defective IMO signage that needs maintenance/ upgradation.The finding was circulated to all Fleet vessels (with countermeasures) to avoid similar findings on other vessels

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
Immediate Cause:
The valve was seized due to internal mechanical wear and build-up of residue over time, which 
restricted its movement and compromised operability.
Root Cause:
Age-related deterioration and lack of regular operation leading to internal corrosion or sticking.
Inadequate preventive maintenance frequency in this specific section of the line.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
Corrective Actions:
The seized vapor isolation valve was removed and replaced with a new unit from onboard spares.
Post-replacement checks were conducted to confirm full functionality and sealing integrity.
The replaced valve was tagged, and the event was logged in the maintenance management system.
A follow-up inspection was carried out by the Classification Society post-installation, confirming that 
valve is in satisfactory working conditions.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: The IP tank vapour isolation valve seized
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
Preventive Actions:
The crew briefed on identifying early signs of valve stiffness during rounds.
A fleet-wide circular was issued to stress the importance of periodic operation of infrequently used 
valves.
YARD: Shina SB Shipyard CO@Tongyoung South Korea

NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Nil findings

The condition of the ship and its Equipment shall be maintained to confirm with the provision of the present regulation to ensure that the ship in all respects will remain fit to proceed to sea without danger to the ship or person on board.
PSCO identified severe rusting on ship cargo tank steam lines.

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
Prior arriving at the Port of Inspection, the Master had diligently verified and signed all record books and arrival checklists. However, amidst the numerous papers, the Master inadvertently overlooked signing the entry in the Oil Record Book dated 12-May-2024, which was noticed by the PSC Inspector during the documentation checks. On observing this, the PSC Inspector raised it as a deficiency. The inspector verified all other pages of Oil record book were signed by the master and the entries in both Part-I and Part-II of the Oil Record Book were found to be in order.
After the deficiency was pointed out, the Master promptly signed the missing date of entry. As a result, the PSC Inspector downgraded the deficiency to code 10.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN: In accordance with Annex 3 "Record Book Guidelines" from the Company’s Environment Energy Management System (EEMS) Manual, all record books, including the Oil Record Book, Cargo Record Book, Garbage Record Book, and Ballast Water Record Book, shall be verified and countersigned by the Master of the vessel at the bottom of each page.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Master not sign oil record book at 12-May-2024.
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
After the deficiency was pointed out, the Master promptly signed the missing date of entry. As a result, the PSC Inspector downgraded the deficiency to code 10.
Taking a positive note from the deficiency, the Vessel Superintendent briefed the Master to conduct verifications and checks on a regular day-to-day basis well before arrival at any port to avoid missing any signatures that could be highlighted during third-party inspections.
To prevent recurrence, the deficiency was shared with all vessels in the fleet.

CAUSE_ANALYSIS: At the time of inspection vessel was loading MEG. In preparation for cargo operations and to address potential emergencies additional precautionary measures were taken by bringing the Portable Resuscitator from hospital to the cargo control room. However, during the hospital inspection, the inspector pointed out the absence of the Portable Artificial Resuscitator from the respective location and raised it as an deficiency.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN: The upkeep and maintenance of Hospital equipment is an integral part of company’s SMS. General hygiene, inventory of medicines and hospital equipment is maintained by the medical officer on weekly and monthly basis. Record of inspection of hospital is also logged down in deck logbook and official logbook. All hospital equipment’s are maintained and kept up to date as per flag requirements and industry standards.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY:
At the time of inspection, Portable artificial resuscitator was found missing in the 
hospital. Ship staff were not aware of its current location.
PSC_CATEGORY: Health protection, medical care, social security
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
The onboard team immediately brought back the portable resuscitator to the hospital.
Master has briefed all the officers regarding the importance of keeping the emergency equipment in their respective location. Additionally training session was conducted for all crew members, emphasizing the significance of observing and maintaining safety equipment in its designated location. To prevent further recurrence deficiency has been sent to all the fleet vessel.

compliance with COLREG requirements.

CAUSE_ANALYSIS: During the voyage, the onboard team performed quarterly checks of all weathertight doors on the vessel. They inspected the doors for signs of corrosion, ensured the dog cleats were properly lubricated and assessed the weathertightness of all deck and accommodation doors. During the deck rounds, the inspector observed that the rubber packing of a weathertight door located on the starboard side of the A-deck accommodation was not properly fitted in the channel, leaving gaps, particularly in the corners. This was classified as a deficiency under Code 17. The inspector also checked the condition of the rubber packing on other weathertight doors and found them to be in good condition.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN: As per company procedures, all weathertight doors must be checked for weathertightness and integrity according to the company's planned maintenance system. In accordance with the company’s PMS, all weathertight doors are to be inspected on quarterly basis. During these inspections, the doors should be examined for signs of corrosion and wear as well as for weather tightness and the condition of the rubber packing.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: W.T rubber packing is not as required.
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
After the deficiency was noted, the onboard team promptly replaced the rubber packing of the weathertight door located on the starboard side of the A-deck accommodation.
Attached are the pictures of the rubber packing after the renewal.
In response to the deficiency, the Vessel Superintendent briefed the Master and Chief Officer on the importance of conducting checks of all weathertight doors according to the planned maintenance system and immediately addressing any abnormalities found.
To prevent a recurrence, the details of this deficiency will be shared with all vessels in the fleet.

NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Nil findings
Alarm column in forecastle and several in engine room not working or malfunctioning.
YARD: SLS SHIPBUILDING CO., LTD.- Tong Yeong, South Korea

NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Solenoid control valve for pneumatic oil discharge valve - air leakage. Crew cannot demonstrate proper test of two oil discharge valves(pneumatic and solenoid).

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
We suspect that the subjected emergency light must have busted due to vibration during maneuvering at the port of inspection. On being pointed out by the inspector the ship staff carried out a risk assessment and lockout/tagout of the emergency light in the Emergency generator room. The fused light was replaced, and the emergency light was found to be working satisfactorily. Same was verified by the inspector before his departure and he noted the observation to be closed out with a code 10. Attached photograph of the renewed emergency light.
Furthermore, as a precautionary measure a comprehensive check of all emergency lighting on board was conducted to ensure they are working satisfactory. Master has confirmed that all other emergency lights are working properly.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
In accordance with the company's procedures, all deck lights, engine room lights, and other service space lights, including emergency lights undergo weekly testing and are checked before the vessel's arrival in port. The vessel's staff confirmed that all deck lights and emergency lights including emergency lights in the emergency generator room had been inspected and tested prior to arrival at the port of inspection and were found to be in satisfactory working condition. Verification of emergency lighting functionality was included in the safety officer's checklist (SF-11B) which was sighted by the inspector.
During his round, all deck and emergency lights were switched on as per the inspector's request, and it was observed that all lights were in proper working order. During deck, accommodation and engine room rounds inspector witnessed that all lights including emergency lights were operational.
However, during the inspection of the emergency generator room, the inspector noticed that one of the emergency light inside the emergency generator room was in-operational and hence raised it as an observation code 17
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Emergency Generator - One emergency light busted.
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
After departure from the port of inspection a briefing was carried out by the master regarding importance of proper functioning on all lights on board including emergency lights and any in- operational light to be immediately bought to the notice of the concerned officer. The safety officer was also counseled regarding capturing in-operational lights during safety rounds.
To prevent the recurrence of similar issues, this observation has been shared with all vessels within our fleet to enhance awareness and adherence to the safety officer checklist.

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
The vessel was scheduled to call at Rotterdam to carry out planned general maintenance and a routine overhaul of machinery in the engine room after completion of Discharge operations. In preparation for this, the management had dispatched additional experts/ riding staff to assess the job scope and identify any additional tasks required for the scheduled maintenance.  They were signed as Supernumeraries in the crew list. 
The team embarked on the vessel at Gibraltar while enroute and were engaged as technical experts under an agreement with their ship repair yard, which encompassed all necessary insurance and liabilities. 
The vessel had got a LOI signed by the repair team, and briefing and Safety familiarization was carried out for them as per company’s SMS procedure for Contractor Safety. 
During the inspection by the PSC, it was noted that the employment status and contractual arrangements of these experts had not been shared with the vessel, as they were not directly employed under the vessel operator's contract. The inspector documented this as an observation.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
-	Upon identification of the observation by the inspector, concerns were raised by the Master with the shore office.  
-	The three Supernumeraries on board were temporarily hired on board as part of riding crew and provided with a separate contract to join the vessel. MI country flag was consulted and confirmed that supernumeraries were not considered as ship’s crew, therefore a valid Basic Training certificate is not applicable for them. 
-	The same was verified and confirmed by the attending Class Surveyor.
-	However, in consideration of the observation, it was collectively decided to sign off the supernumeraries on an immediate basis, ensuring compliance and transparency in accordance with all relevant regulations.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: The certificate of proficiency for Basic Training of supernumary Y. Bondarenko is expired.
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION: -	This observation has been shared with all fleet vessels. All were asked to verify that deficiencies raised in the PSC inspection are not present on board in order to prevent recurrence.

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
Basic Cause
 Evidence that free fall lifeboat and rescue boat maneuvered in the water in the past three months could not be presented on board.
Immediate Cause
 Master presented evidence of lowering of the lifeboat at port Gove Australia on june 22, 2022 however the painter was not released during the lowering.
 Master was confused with the mail received from the agents at Gove, asking for the boat to be connected with the vessel at all times as per Australian boarder force. This has created a doubt in the mind of Master and hence the retention of the painter connected to the boat after launching.
 Inadequate compliance with solas requirements ( Regulation III / 19.3.4.4) Free fall life boats shall be launched and maneuvered in the water every three months.
Root Cause
 Inadequate standards in checking vessel reports especially the systems of carrying out quarterly boat drill to ensure they meet the requirements.
 Inadequate compliance in meeting the requirements of SOLAS (Regulation III / 19.3.4.4).
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
 Lowering and maneuvering performed at Singapore Anchorage on 13th August 2022, painter was released, LB and RB maneuver on the water.
 Reported to AMSA after carrying out the drill. Received confirmation from AMSA.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Evidence that free-fall lifeboat and rescue boat maneuvered in the water in the past three months could not be prepared on board. Evidence of last time lifeboat and rescue boat were manuevered could not be presented onboard.
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
 Crew to adhere with company procedures regarding plan of contingency drills (Reference – company form SF-19A)
 Master briefly discussed with crew requirements as per SOLAS (Regulation III / 19.3.4.4) Freefall lifeboat shall be launched and maneuvered in the water without painter connected to lifeboat / rescue boat and to perform every three months.
 Master to seek permission to QHSE as per Managers Instruction 08/2020 – guidelines for lowering and maneuvering of lifeboat into the water along with Risk Assessment and Training prior lowering of the boats.
 Observation to be included as part of the briefing in the office for all crew prior joining the ship.
 Deficiency to be shared across the fleet for their awareness and prevention.
 Company’s PIC to closely check the content of submitted minutes of contingency drills in ShipPalm.
 This matter should be included in the next meeting and discussed with all crew for their awareness.
 QHSE department requires the vessel to submit photos of the lifeboat lowering and same to review thoroughly if launching is being carried out as per SOLAS requirements.

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
a)	Scupper Valve not closing completely to the satisfaction of PSC inspector. It was immediately verified and made operational to the satisfaction of the PSC inspector and Class Surveyor. 
b)	Accommodation scupper drain line thinned down /holed and temporary repairs carried out. The Strom valve ceased in open position.
c)	Lack of training in handling and maintenance.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
a)	The accommodation drain storm valve eased up and now freely closing and opening. DD spec raised to renew wasted pipeline at dry dock.
b)	Class NK had issued COC for the leaking pipeline to be repaired in the upcoming dry dock.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: The overboard accommodation drain through hull on port aft lower floor engine room is deteriorated by corrosion and leaky (temporarily repaired by epoxy but seawater blisters already appearing). The scupper valave of this drain can not be closed. Evidence of rectification by class/flag to be send to the PSC office before departure.
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
a)	All storm valves are to be greased and the operation of valves to be checked monthly. 
b)	Overboard pipe lagging to open and inspect on a periodical basis to access the pipe condition.
c)	All Strom valves replaced with new ones in drydock.

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
a)	Self-priming unit in fire/bilge/ballast pump was operational during the psc inspection however the psc inspector was not satisfied with the engaging unit operational condition. Same was reviewed and further checked by the Class NK Surveyor for good operational condition
b)	Self priming unit for Fire/GS pump is not in place. On verifying noted that foundation was not available, but the drawing was indicating priming pump. Priming pump requirement is applicable only for Bilge pump. As foundation not available, it was confirmed that this pump was in place without priming pump, but in good operational condition. The drawing may be only for reference as both the pumps are identical, and one pump has a priming unit. This was verified and confirmed by attending Class Surveyor.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
a)	Overhauled self-priming pump, made drive clutch engaged and operational. 
b)	Class NK had issued COC for suction pipeline temporary repair work and permanent repairs to be done in the upcoming dry dock.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Forward fire/bilge/ballast pump self priming unit is not operational. Aft fire/general service pump self priming unit is missing. Only drivewheel in place. Suction line of aft pump is repaired with epoxy. Evidence of rectification by class/flag to be sent to PSC office before departure.
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
a)	Fire Bilge and Ballast pump top cover and casing ordered to replace and priming unit to connect with the pump.
b)	Regular inspection to carry out and check the operation on a weekly basis and record the status.
c)	Wasted and holed suction pipe section of Fire and G.S pump for renewed in DD

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
Immediate Cause:
• Maintenance work was carried out on the L.O. and F.O. section pumps, but residual oil and 
cleaning were not adequately addressed post-maintenance.
Root Cause:
• The cleaning of affected areas was not performed immediately after maintenance, leaving 
visible traces of oil.
• Insufficient oversight to ensure that the work area was restored to a clean state following 
maintenance.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
Corrective Actions:
• Cleaned the purifier room, specifically the areas around the L.O. and F.O. section pumps, to 
remove all oil traces.
• Conducted a thorough inspection to ensure no active leaks were present post-maintenance.
• Verified the functionality of the L.O. and F.O. section pumps to confirm no further issues.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: L.O., F.O., section pumps, inside purifier room leakage
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
Preventive Actions:
• Conducted training sessions for the engineering team on the importance of cleaning and 
maintaining work areas after maintenance to ensure compliance operators standards.
• Observation circulated to all vessels for information sharing and learning.
YARD: Shina SB Shipyard CO@Tongyoung South Korea

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
Immediate Cause:
• The exposed location of the life raft deck prevented completion of maintenance due to 
adverse weather conditions.
Root Cause:
• The life raft deck is continuously exposed to weather elements, accelerating corrosion.
• Maintenance work could not be completed in the current voyage due to weather constraints.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
Corrective Actions:
• The concerned areas are being hydro blasted and primer application is in progress.
• The maintenance task will be completed during the upcoming voyage.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Liferafts deck p/s hull &frames corroded
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
Preventive Actions:
• Schedule routine maintenance of exposed areas like the life raft deck during favourable 
weather conditions or sheltered ports to prevent delays.
• Include the life raft deck and associated structures in the routine inspection schedule to 
identify and address early signs of corrosion.
• Critical maintenance tasks exposed to adverse weather to be conducted on priority on good 
weather days
YARD: Shina SB Shipyard CO@Tongyoung South Korea

CAUSE_ANALYSIS: As per the company procedure, all seafarers joining the vessel are provided with a valid seafarer's employment contract in accordance with MLC and flag state requirements. The wages and employment conditions are based on the latest CBA in force with respect to the concerned vessel. While preparing the contract for the General Steward and Trainee OS, the PIC in charge of the subject vessel correctly input all the details in the seafarer's employment contract. However, he inadvertently selected the incorrect rank. This omission was not verified by the manning superintendent prior to issuing the SEA. Furthermore, the Trainee OS and General Steward did not verify the SEA before signing it prior to joining the vessel. Additionally, upon signing, the master did not compare the rank of the crew as per the latest CBA, leading to this deficiency.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN: During the documentation, the PSCO checked the MLC records, such as crew contract, flag state documents and wages settlement of the crew. Upon comparing the Seafarer's employment contract with the CBA, the PSCO observed that the rank mentioned as General Steward and Trainee OS on the seafarer's employment contract does not match the CBA ranks. All other details, such as basic wages and overtime details, were found to be in accordance with the CBA. Hence the PSCO raised it as a deficiency
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Found on board general steward and trainee OS. These functions are mentioned in seamans book and SEA. In CBA IBF JSU these functions/ranks are not mentioned.
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
Upon being pointed out by the inspector, the manning office was informed about the discrepancy between the CBA and SEA. The PIC in charge in the office sent a revised SEA for the General Steward and Trainee OS as per the latest IBF-JSU/NUSI/MUI CBA effective from 1st January 2024. The revised SEA was accepted by the General Steward and the Trainee OS. The inspector checked the revised SEA and closed the deficiency.

The PIC in charge was counselled by senior management in the office to ensure that the SEA for all crew joining fleet vessels is checked for correct references to the applicable CBA, correct wage scales, and specific requirements or regulations of the Marshall Island flag to be always complied with. Additionally, the master and crew have been briefed by the superintendent to check and compare the SEA details as per the latest CBA, and in case of any discrepancies, these should be notified to the manning office and get it corrected.

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
Overview of the Finding:
During a routine inspection and update of the SOPEP manual, the officer in charge observed that the 
plastic envelope used to store the port contact list had deteriorated and required replacement. The 
contact list was removed with the intention of updating it with a fresh copy. However, due to an 
oversight, the updated list was not placed back into the SOPEP manual. As a result, during the PSC 
inspection, the inspector noted the missing SOPEP list of port contacts, leading to this observation.
Root Cause:
The root cause of this issue is attributed to inadequate follow-up.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
Correction:
The SOPEP list of port contacts was immediately updated with the latest and correct information for 
all relevant port. The updated list has been reviewed and re-filed properly in the SOPEP manual 
onboard.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: SOPEP list of port contacts not updated
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
Corrective/Preventive Action:
To prevent recurrence of this issue, the following steps have been implemented:
The responsible officer is briefed to review the SOPEP documentation before every port.
The Master will conduct quarterly reviews of the SOPEP list to ensure its accuracy and proper 
maintenance.The effectiveness of these corrective and preventive actions will be monitored through regular 
internal audits and the quarterly review process. The QHSE department will also conduct spot checks 
during vessel inspections to verify that the SOPEP contact list remains updated and compliant.

CAUSE_ANALYSIS: During the Engine Room rounds, the Inspector observed minor oil deposits in the area around the circulating pump near the Main Engine fuel oil heater. Consequently, this was raised as a deficiency under Code 17. After the deficiency was noted, the onboard team promptly cleaned the affected areas and removed the minor oil deposits near the Main Engine fuel oil heater. The Master has confirmed that the area around the Main Engine fuel oil heater has been cleaned and is now free of any oil stains
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN: The company’s Safety management system provides detailed guidelines for maintenance and overhauling of Main Engines and their associated components. This maintenance and inspection regime is drawn up as per makers specific guidelines on component overhaul intervals and is incorporated in company’s computerized Planned Maintenance System. On the day of the inspection, the onboard team noticed an oil deposit near the circulating pump of the Main Engines. Upon identifying the oil deposit, the onboard team promptly carried out an investigation to identify the source of the leak. After investigation, the onboard team found the discharge pressure gauge of No. 3 unit of Main Engine fuel oil supply pump leaking. The onboard team promptly changed the discharge pressure gauge. However, the onboard team inadvertently missed out cleaning the oil deposit near the leakage area.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: M/E fuel heater area (circulation pump) found dirty
PSC_SUB_CATEGORY: Oil and oily mixtures from machinery spaces
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION: Attached are pictures of the Main Engine fuel oil heater area near the circulating pump after cleaning. Taking a positive note from the observation, the Vessel Superintendent held a thorough briefing with senior management and the Engine Room Staff, highlighting the crucial importance of maintaining the Engine Room in optimal condition. There was particular emphasis on the hazards linked to oil leakages around the machinery in the Engine Room. To address and resolve the identified issues, management has reaffirmed the necessity of conducting a thorough cleaning of the Engine Room before the vessel departs from port. To prevent recurrence, the observation has been shared with all fleet vessels.
YARD: NEW TIMES SHIP BUILDING CO LTD,CHINA

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
Vessel is outfitted with two boiler feed water pumps. The feed water pumps are situated on
the boiler platform in the engine room. During his rounds in the engine room the inspector
noted that Boiler was well maintained, However he noted that the safety guard on NO-1 Feed
pump was removed and kept on the floor and the safety guard for the No-2 Feed Pump was
improperly mounted exposing to rotating part .Hence the inspector noted it as a deficiency
code 40 ac. Upon Investigation it was noted that routine inspection of the boiler motor was
carried out prior arrival at the port of inspection. After completion of the Inspection the
concerned staff inadvertently missed putting back the safety guard on Boiler Feed pump No-1
and did not properly put back the safety guard for feed pump No-2. This was noted by the
PSCO during his rounds in the Engine Room . 
3. Correction of the finding
On being pointed out by the inspector the ship staff immediately placed back the safety guard for
No-1 boiler feed water pump and the safety guard on boiler feed water pump No-2 was correctly
placed back. The chief engineer has confirmed that the feed water pump was not used after
completion of the last routine inspection carried out prior arrival to the port of inspection.
Class attended the vessel at Barcelona on 14th May-24 and verified closure of the deficiency.
USCG were notified regarding class attendance and verification by class. USCG has confirmed that
the deficiency has been closed out in their system
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
Observation is regarding safety guard missing /Improperly mounted on both the boiler feed
water pump. Company Health and safety manual Chapter 16 “Safe operation practices” has a
separate section of Working on Machinery with rotating parts. As per this section it is company
requirement that Correct safety guards for appliances should be securely fixed before starting
any operation.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: PSCO observed guards missing / improperly mounted around both boiler freed water pumps.
PSC_CATEGORY: Working and Living Conditions - Working Conditions
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
4. Corrective/Preventive action based on the root cause
Taking a serious note from the deficiency pointed out by the PSCO the attending
superintendent carried out a briefing of the Master and chief engineer re-emphasizing the
importance of using all machinery with proper safety guard. After completion of
inspection/routine maintenance safety guards to be put back in place and confirmed by the
responsible officer.
5. What is the plan to monitor the effectiveness of the corrective/preventive actions?
a. To avoid recurrence the observation shall be shared with vessels within the fleet to ensure
compliance.
b. During Internal Audits/Vessel inspections verification of compliance with company procedure
to protect crew from dangers associated with moving parts, Hot Surface hazard is carried out.
This includes verification of use of safety guard of machinery is verified

NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Nil findings
YARD: Hyundai Mipo Dockyard Ulsan, South Korea

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
Identification of Root Cause:
1. The current cleaning protocols and their frequency are insufficient, particularly after maintenance activities. This results in the accumulation of dirt and contaminants in critical areas of the Engine Room, impacting overall cleanliness.
2. Before the vessel's arrival, there was a leak in the Purifier room, leading to stains on the drip tray. Leaks were arrested but cleaning was in progress.
3. The area around the Auxiliary Engine was found to be dirty during maintenance.
4. Due to the excessive workload on the Auxiliary Engine, the crew was unable to catch up with cleaning tasks.
Correction of the Finding:
1.
Immediate cleaning of the purifier room and main engine carried out.
2.
Conducted a thorough inspection to identify and address any immediate issues caused by suboptimal cleanliness.
3.
Additional crew joined the vessel for cleaning and painting at Gibraltar for upbringing the ER cleaning. 4.
An additional Engine Fitter was placed onboard for Aux Engine repair.
Corrective/Preventive Action based on the Root Cause:
1.
Revised and implemented a more stringent and comprehensive cleaning schedule for the Engine Room.
2.
Attending Superintendent Conducted targeted training sessions to educate crew members on the significance of cleanliness for equipment performance and safety.
3.
Established routine audits to ensure adherence to the new cleaning schedule and standards.
4.
Attending superintendent Emphasized cleanliness criteria in regular safety drills and inspections.
Plan to Monitor the Effectiveness of the Corrective/Preventive Actions:
Monitoring Plan:
1.
Schedule office staff visit at next convenient port to evaluate the cleanliness of the Engine Room.
2.
Conduct periodic training sessions to reinforce cleanliness protocols and assess crew understanding.
3.
Include cleanliness as a dedicated agenda item in routine safety meetings onboard and in office monthly meetings.
This plan is designed to address immediate concerns, establish preventive measures, and implement a monitoring framework to sustain cleanliness standards in the Engine Room over time. Regular communication, training, and audits will be pivotal in fostering a continuous culture of cleanliness and safety awareness among the crew.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN: Overview of the Finding: The cleanliness of the Engine Room, with specific attention to the purifier room and main engine, requires improvement. Vessel staff has carried out Routine Maintenance in the purifier room and other machinery after Transiting SUEZ canal with help of a riding fitters. Vessel staff completed planned maintenance in engine room and started cleaning , drying and mopping of engine room floor. Cleaning was in progress at the time of the PSC Inspection.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Cleanliness of Engine Room has to be improved, especially to purifier room and to main engine.
PSC_CATEGORY: Health protection, medical care, social security
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
The Observation has been noted with a serious concern at our end. Telephonic briefing of senior management was carried out by senior management ashore to take note of status quo onboard pertaining to upkeep of engine room. The management has reiterated to keep engine room house keeping in top order and all the area near the machinery to be thoroughly cleaned after completion of the maintenance job.
The Master had informed that Engine room machinery spaces has been cleaned and there was No oil stains noted within the machinery spaces. Photograph of machinery Auxiliary engine cases has been attached.
This observation has been shared with the Fleet vessels to emphasize that all the area near the machinery to be thoroughly cleaned immediately after completion of the maintenance job.
YARD: Shina SB Yard Co. Ltd. Tong Yeong,South Korea

NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Nil findings

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
a) Equipment Malfunction: On investigation the MF/HF DSC antenna cable in the junction box was
found to be rusted, damaged and the connection had become loose resulting in low PA power.
b) Incorrect testing procedure: Vessel staff were testing MF/HF DSC with other vessels as they could
not receive a response from any other coast station in the region.
c) Incomplete entries made in GMDSS log by responsible OOW and oversight by the Master during
his verification of GMDSS logbook.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: The DSC testcalls for MF/HF, VHF could not be demonstrated with acknowledgement from coast staions. In the recordbook the last testcall ship to ship was not identiefied with a MMSI number of the partical vessel.
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
a) The maker’sservice technician attended the vessel on 28th Sep 2023 to check the MF/HF and VHF
units onboard.
b) Troubleshooting was carried out for MF/HF and the fault was found to be rusted & damaged
antenna cable in the junction box for MF/HF DSC. The rusted cable was cleaned and securely
connected in the junction box. The MF/HF DSC was then found to be in working condition and
tested successfully by the service technician. MF/HF DSC was successfully tested with
Netherlands cost station on 28th Sep 2023 by the ship staff in presence of service technician.
c) VHF DSC was in working condition with no defects. Vessel could successfully test VHF DSC with
Netherlands coast station.
d) The company superintendent carried out training sessions for all deck officers for correct testing
procedure of GMDSS equipment and correct procedure to make entries in GMDSS logbook (as
per company guidelines).
e) The defect was rectified on 28th Sep 2023 and verified by the Class surveyor.
f) This deficiency was closed by the PSCO on 30th Sep 2023.

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
Immediate Cause
➢ Unlit emergency lights
Basic Cause –
➢ Lights are affected by ship’s vibration leading to busting.
➢ PIC not checking the emergency lights outside accommodation while vessel is at berth.
Root Cause – ➢ PIC performed arrival checklist however, inadequate verification after vessel is alongside. ➢ Inadequate verification by Master and Chief Engineer to check all emergency lights outside crew accommodation. ➢ Inadequate compliance with company procedures as per bridge checklist (Book 7 – OP-09G) preparation for arrival in port.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
➢ PIC immediately changed busted emergency lights outside accommodation exit.
➢ Re-inspected by PSCO and closed on the spot.
➢ Briefed and educated PIC to check all emergency lights outside crew accommodation before and after vessel is made fast alongside. Training Record (SF-17) was completed.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Starboard Side navigation light not working
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
➢ Master and PIC to adhere procedures as per bridge checklist (OP-O9G) preparation for arrival in port.
➢ Discuss amongst crew during monthly and pre-arrival meeting (SF-12)
➢ PIC must verify that all emergency lights are in good working condition while vessel is at sea and in port.
➢ Chief Engineer to randomly check and verify condition of emergency lights outside crew accommodation while vessel is at berth.
➢ To include in hand-over notes to incoming crew and to highlight sighted deficiency.
➢ Information to be shared throughout the fleet reminding the Master and crew for above observation

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
Malfunction of rudder angle indicators on bridge due to synchronization error. 
Local Ruder angle indicator in steering gear room was working satisfactorily and readily available for 
safe navigation. 
Flag dispensation was readily available and valid until 12 April 2024. 
All recommendations as per Flag and risk assessment was complied with. 
Notification was sent to all parties; Maker’s attendance was planned at the first convenient 
port/upon vessel berthing on 12 March 2024 to rectify the error. 
Rudder Angle Indicator was made operational and tested successfully prior departure from Lisbon on 
12 March 2024.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
Vessel experienced bridge rudder angle indicators showing offset readings by few degrees compared to 
actual rudder position. 
An unexpected malfunction/synchronization error rendered rudder angle indicators temporarily 
inoperable during the inspection. 
Local ruder angle indicator in steering gear room was working satisfactorily and readily available for safe 
navigation and witnessed by the PSC inspector during the inspection including communication/plans with 
regards to troubleshooting. 
Vessel Flag, class and port authorities were duly informed and appropriate Flag dispensation valid until 12 
April 2024 was available and shown to the PSC inspector. 
Bridge team were briefed about all the precautions as per the risk assessment carried out for above 
condition and records were witnessed by the inspector.
Upon identification of the malfunction, technical team promptly initiated the necessary troubleshooting 
procedures to rectify the issue and correct offsets readings. 
Basis outcome of onboard and shore based remote troubleshooting by service engineer as per maker’s 
guidelines, fault attributed to synchronization errors despite best efforts to resolve the fault remotely. 
Service engineer attended vessel upon berthing in Lisbon on 12 March 2024 to rectify the error. 
Rudder angle indicators troubleshooting and synchronizations was successfully completed, service report 
attached for reference. 
Closure message regarding successful completion of the work was sent to PSC official and 
acknowledgement received regarding the same. Communication with PSC is attached for reference. 
Vessel crew were briefed by the attending technical superintendent. 
Above observation shall be shared in company’s monthly finding list to raise awareness.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: PS/SB/Central rudder angle indicator found out of order (Class NKK and flage are aware condition to repair in next DD)
R_OWNERS: Global United Gas Carriers Pte. Ltd.
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
Vessel experienced bridge rudder angle indicators showing offset readings by few degrees compared to 
actual rudder position. 
An unexpected malfunction/synchronization error rendered rudder angle indicators temporarily 
inoperable during the inspection.

navigation and witnessed by the PSC inspector during the inspection including communication/plans with 
regards to troubleshooting.

April 2024 was available and shown to the PSC inspector. 
Bridge team were briefed about all the precautions as per the risk assessment carried out for above 
condition and records were witnessed by the inspector.
Upon identification of the malfunction, technical team promptly initiated the necessary troubleshooting 
procedures to rectify the issue and correct offsets readings.

Service engineer attended vessel upon berthing in Lisbon on 12 March 2024 to rectify the error.

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
Immediate Cause:
During the vessel's passage to China, it encountered rough weather with strong winds and
vibrations, causing the red all-around light on the port side to malfunction.
The routine pre-arrival testing of navigational lights was not completed the following day
due to the vessel’s arrival schedule. During the inspection, the malfunction was identified.
Root Cause:
1. Mechanical stress: Prolonged exposure to adverse weather conditions caused
vibrations and wear that led to the failure of the light.
2. Operational lapse: Routine pre-arrival testing of navigational lights was missed,
resulting in the malfunction not being identified and addressed before the
inspection.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
Corrective Actions:
1. Replaced the faulty red all-around light with a functioning unit to restore
compliance with navigational safety requirements.
2. Conducted a complete inspection and operational test of all navigational lights on
board to ensure no additional issues.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: One red all around light on the port side unlit.
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
Preventive Actions:
1. Conducted training sessions for the crew on the importance of verifying
navigational and safety equipment after rough weather conditions.
2. Shared the observation fleetwide to highlight the importance of routine testing and
maintenance of navigational lights and equipment to prevent similar issues.
YARD: Shina SB Shipyard CO@Tongyoung South Korea

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
The Emergency showers onboard are maintained according to the Planned Maintenance System (PMS) requirements.
Regular testing of the Emergency showers and eyewash stations is to be conducted prior to the ship’s arrival, as per the company’s cargo transfer checklist (OP-CHEM-04) and Pre-Arrival checklist (OP-18C). 
During the inspection, the inspector verified that these checklists were completed. 
During the deck rounds, the inspector tested the Emergency Showers on deck. While testing the Emergency shower, it was noted that there was a leak from the piping. Hence the inspector noted this as an observation. 
Upon investigation it was identified that the vessel during her discharge was experiencing sub-zero temperatures however the vessel had kept ready the emergency eyewash ready for operation, but the heating arrangement of the pipelines was not kept running during the stay, which resulted in icing and cracking of the eyewash line and resulted in the leak. Due to the crack in the pipe and loosening of the rust, when the emergency shower was tested the drain nozzles accumulated rust particles from the pipeline and resulted in the eyewash water to become black upon testing.

Root cause identified. 
-	Inadequate Safety officer inspection as per procedures. (Ref: HSM Ch 5 Safety Inspection and reporting)
-	Inadequate pre arrival Cold weather checks
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
-	The ship staff immediately removed the damaged pipeline and fabricated a new one in the workshop, after obtaining necessary permission from the Port authorities. 
-	The remaining sections of the pipeline were flushed thoroughly to ensure no rust deposits were remaining in the pipeline. 
-	The attending class surveyor has verified the completed rectification efforts, ensuring compliance with industry standards and regulations.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Line of emergency eye wash station midships leaking severe amount of water. Eye wash water has black colour.
PSC_CATEGORY: Health protection, medical care, social security
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
-	Training was carried out by the Company Superintendent for all crew and Master has been instructed to Implement regular inspections of provision stores and meat and fish rooms identify and address maintenance issues promptly. 
-	The ship staff was counselled about the importance of testing equipment every watch to ensure its proper functioning. Emphasizing the significance of thorough checks, the crew members were reminded to verify that heating and draining of the eyewash line when not use especially in colder climates.
-	This observation has been shared with all fleet vessels. All vessels were asked to verify that deficiencies raised in the PSC inspection are not present on board when calling such ports, and pre arrival checks are carried out

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
Meanwhile a risk assessment has been carried out for loading/discharging operation in present 
condition, where adequate portable lighting is always provided overside to make the draft marks 
more easily legible at aft end throughout any cargo operation. Further the vessels crew always 
compares the draft from all the Six draft marks visually with the loadicator and logs in the port log 
every watch. These measures were sighted by the Inspector. 
Vessel hull Painting carried out in drydock at China on 13-Mar-2024. All the draft marks were newly
painted.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
This observation is regarding fading of paint from the permanent welded draft numbering at stern of 
the vessel. The Vessel has been engaged in frequent port calls and due to friction with mooring 
ropes, tug lines, paint got eroded off at places on stern draft marks. However, the draft marking was 
still clearly visible despite the fading contrasting paint at several places. Further, the midship and the 
aft draft marks were also inspected during the course of the inspection and were noted to be in good 
condition.
Inspection and maintenance of ship side markings is part of the planned maintenance system and 
any damages or defects noted is captured in the computerized PMS. The ship side, draft marks and 
the load lines are regularly inspected and touched upon at all available opportunities. At the last port 
of call, the vessel staff had identified that the forward draft marks needs to be re-painted or touched 
up in places. However, at the previous port as well as in the inspection port, vessel did not get 
permission from port authority to carry out the job of painting of the aft draft markings. Accordingly, 
the job of painting the draft marks was postponed until the next port of call. Vessel staff shall check 
at every port to identify any opportunity to complete the re-painting and touching up of the draft 
marks provided the weather is conducive and the port provides permission.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Number of draft in the Aft is not clear.
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
The observation was circulated among the fleet vessels reiterating the importance of verifying the 
condition of draft marks during draft checks and carrying out routine maintenance on draft marking 
at every opportunity even if there is slightest deterioration or fading of the paint markings.
YARD: NEW TIMES SHIP BUILDING CO LTD,CHINA

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
PMS was implemented on board however it was inadequately followed. (Ref: Tech Manual Ch 3).
The structural condition of lifeboat davit arm was inadequately assessed by the ship staff by doing
a close-up inspection and hammer test.
b) Defect reporting as required by Company procedures was not carried out. (Ref: SMM Ch 15B).
c) Inadequate Safety officer inspection as per procedures. (Ref: HSM Ch 5 Safety Inspection and
reporting).
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: The frame of the freefall lifeboat davit support is holed by corrosion.
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
Approved lifeboat davit service engineers boarded the vessel on 27th Sep 2023 and carried out an
inspection of the complete lifeboat davit unit. Repair scope was agreed between the service
engineer and Class surveyors.Hot work was required to repair the lifeboat davit.
c) Vessel was made gas free by cleaning & ventilating all her cargo tanks. Vessel was certified Gas
free by the Port Chemist on 3rd Oct 2023.
d) Repairs were carried out on the lifeboat davit and all defects were rectified by the shore
workshop and verified by the Class surveyor on 6th Oct 2023.
e) This deficiency was closed by the PSCO on 6th Oct 2023.

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
Immediate Cause
➢ Ballast flooded in cargo Hold no.4 using D1 method on 12th & 13th of May 2022 due to vessel heavily rolling while crew performing hold cleaning.
Basic Cause
➢ PIC not familiar with BWM convention as evidence by discharging ballast in cargo hold no.4 without treatment on 12th & 13th of May 2022.
➢ The IBWMC was issued on 8th March 2021 without the notation that D-1 shall be used only as contingency.
Root Cause ➢ Inadequate compliance to BWM Convention.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN: ➢ Applied for re-issuance of BWMC with notation that D1 might be used for contingency measures only.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: The key person not familiar with BWM convention as evidence by discharging ballast in C/H no. 4 without treatment on 12th and 13th of May 2022.
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
➢ To verify BWMC of fleet vessels if arrangement is as per MMC 345.
➢ To closely monitor ballast handling log & other related records.
➢ To ensure training records are maintained in accordance to BWMP.

➢ Inadequate cleaning of workplace after an operation.
➢ Inadequate compliance to Technical Manual 1.7 - Safe Working Practices.

➢ Chief Engineer briefed & discussed with crew to maintain good housekeeping of machinery spaces.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Oil accumulation in engine room/in engine room, purifier number one found with leakage
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
➢ Chief Engineer to discuss his standing orders to all duty Engineers and Oilers, especially regarding visual inspection/rounds of all running pieces of machinery at regular intervals.
➢ Masters and Chief Engineers to comply with the procedures as per Technical Manual 1.7 Safe Working Practices.
➢ Fleet Alert to be circulated to managed vessels for awareness.

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
Failure to Follow Procedure 
Vessel was taken over by Columbus Shipmanagement on 15 Dec 2023 and the muster list 
duties were prepared and posted by ship staff. 
However the muster list did not specify duties for launching / lowering of liferaft and the 
muster list was not reviewed thoroughly before posting.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
The muster list duties were verified by master, duties for launching / lowering of life raft 
in emergency were added and the updated muster list were posted at all common 
alleyways, ECR and Bridge.

Muster list incomplete; no mention about launching/ lowering of life rafts; furthermore 
muster list missing in engine room / ECR
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
Master briefed all ships crew for the updated emergency duties and verified crew 
members understanding of duties.

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
a) Training and Competency Gaps: The deficiency may be rooted in inadequate training and competency 
levels among crew members and staff responsible for safety. This could result in a lack of understanding 
and adherence to ISM Code requirements. 
b) Lack of Procedure compliance.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
An internal audit was scheduled from the company’s end. Auditor 
was onboard during the Inspection. He completed the internal audit by the next port and 
generated the report.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Corrective action taken on the ISM system by the company is required within 3 months. Deficiency(s) marked ISM is(are) objective evidence of a failure, or lack of effectiveness, of the implementation of the ISM code. The ship will be eligible for reinspection after 3 months from the final date of the report.
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
a) Foster a safety-first culture within the organization, starting with management 
commitment to safety principles and practices by conducting planned safety meetings 
and motivating the crew to follow a good safety culture. 
b) Implement standardized and efficient documentation and record-keeping practices for 
safety-related procedures, incidents, and corrective actions.
