CAUSE_ANALYSIS: Due to frequent use of the fire door on Accommodation B-deck the self-closing hydraulic door closure pressure was reduced which resulted in the door not getting closed completely. Upon being pointed out the self-closing device was adjusted immediately in presence of inspector to ensure the fire door closed properly. The adjustment was carried out by using the adjustment screw on the self-closing device. The inspector after witnessing the fire door getting closed completely downgraded the deficiency as rectified before departure.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN: Vessel arrived at Vancouver on 14th November 2023 for loading her nominated cargo. The Company’s Computerized PMS contains weekly, Monthly, and 3 Monthly maintenance jobs for Fire doors. Positive pressure was maintained effectively within in the accommodation spaces throughout the port stay. The same was verified by the inspector. The Fire Door referred to in the Observation was in a closed condition at the time of the inspection; however, when the Inspector was trying it out, he found that the hydraulic door closer was not completely effective.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY:
Fire door at accommodation deck (midship), on B deck not closing 
properly at the time of inspection.
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION: To prevent recurrence the Master has carried out a briefing of all the ship staff. All crew have been advised to report such deficiencies in a timely manner. Safety officer was instructed to carry out thorough inspection of all fire doors during weekly rounds and to rectify the fault immediately in case the fire doors are not closing completely. Taking a serious note, the deficiency has also been circulated within the fleet vessels to ensure that such conditions are identified and same rectified immediately.

NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Nil findings

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
The root causes of the finding include:
•	Failure to follow procedures as per Fuel Management Plan Ch 7.1
•	Inadequate supervision and checks by the senior engineers.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN: -	Upon identification of the omission by the inspector, immediate corrective measures were implemented. The missing logbook entries were promptly completed
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Wrong entries (HSFO and LSFO content) were used in FOBAS calculator when ship was entering SECA 1st jan 2024. The volume of each low sulpher fuel tank was not written in engineroom log book when changing over 1st of jan 2024.
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
-	To prevent similar oversights in the future, The ship's staff received a comprehensive briefing by the company Superintendents, emphasizing the importance of meticulous logbook record-keeping to prevent such oversights. Training was conducted to reinforce awareness regarding the critical importance of accurate logbook entries. U932-	Upon identification of the observation by the inspector, concerns were raised by the Master with the shore office.  
-	The three Supernumeraries on board were temporarily hired on board as part of riding crew and provided with a separate contract to join the vessel. MI country flag was consulted and confirmed that supernumeraries were not considered as ship’s crew, therefore a Seafarer’s employment agreement is not applicable for them. 
-	The same was verified and confirmed by the attending Class Surveyor
-	However, in consideration of the observation, it was collectively decided to sign off these supernumeraries on an immediate basis, ensuring compliance and transparency in accordance with all relevant regulations.

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
Company SMS duly covers the requirements for safe access between ship and shore. It also includes 
guidelines and risk assessment for safe rigging of the gangway and safety net to be used below the 
Gangway as part of the safe access. 
After vessels arrival at the port of inspection, ships gangway was rigged as means of access. The 
gangway was also covered with the safety net as part of the safe access requirement. The rigging of 
gangway and safety net has been verified by the PSC inspector during boarding. 
However, the safety net used below gangway was covering the area between shipside and gangway 
to shorter length. It was noted to be not having clear run to broadly cover the area between shipside 
to gangway extremities. Same was noticed by the inspector and raised as an deficiency under code 
17.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
Immediately after the deficiency was raised, corrective action was taken by connecting the spare 
safety net with In-use safety net. Thereafter, safety net was rigged properly to cover the area 
completely between shipside to gangway and below the gangway. Same was verified by the inspector 
prior departure and deficiency was marked as corrected with code 10.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Safety net for gangway not be cover completely.
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
Additionally, requisition was raised for supply of the new gangway net of larger area to properly cover 
the area below gangway and between shipside and gangway. In the meantime, risk assessment was 
carried out for use of present safety net. The present safety net is being inspected regularly and prior 
every use to verify its condition till the time new safety is supplied to the vessel. 
After departure from the port, Marine superintendent carried out the briefing of the Master and 
senior officer on the importance of properly rigging of the gangway safety net. It was also conveyed 
that the regular checks to be carried out to verify the means of safe access and any shortcomings to 
be informed to office immediately to take corrective action. 
 The deficiency has been shared among the fleet vessels to avoid recurrence.

NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Nil findings

CAUSE_ANALYSIS: Inadequate supervision by senior management wherein the tasks allocated to operational staff required to be monitored and suitable action plan implemented. In this case personnel in charge of updating of charts/publications onboard required to be instructed with the requirement to keep ECDIS back up system updated.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
Bridge team meeting held and requirement to keep ECDIS back up system always updated briefed. 
An additional barrier enforced by way of secondary personnel allocated with same duties of updating the charts/publications so that effective implementation is completed.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Back up arrangement for electronic nautical publication not corrected up to date
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
Master briefed with the gravity of the defect.
Master’s Handing over notes proposed to include physical checks with Incoming Master for status of charts/publications onboard. 
Back up software provider CC Marine proposed whether they can send reminders on vessel in case of charts requiring updating as an when required.
Defect circulated among all vessels for awareness and to prevent similar re-occurrence.

AREA_OF_CONCERN: Ch VII/ Maritime Security - (Policies and Procedures)
CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
Basic Cause
 Incorrect arrangement of locking device fixed on security door.
 Failure to communicate/coordinate the location of key.
 Improper position of the locking device installed for security purposes of access door. Padlock should be installed from the outside of any access door where it can be opened while crew from the inside can easily open the security door in case of emergency purposes to exit.
Immediate Cause
 Improper position for the locking device.
 Inadequate communication between the crew who secure the door and PSC inspector.
 Lack of awareness by crew in failing to identify wrong/incorrect securing arrangement.
Root Cause
 Inadequate checking on efficacy of onboard locking arrangement of all access doors.
 Inadequate compliance with safety. Security was prioritized over the safety of crew
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
 Inform all onboard crew and personnel the location of the key to be use in case of emergency exit.
 The previous locking arrangement was re-designed to facilitate safe accessibility of access door. Crew fabricated locking device with wing nut from the inside which can be operated/opened easily during emergency while the padlock can be locked from the outside.
 Additional plate was installed to cover the access door (grill type/design) in order to avoid opening the wing nut from the outside.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Ship Security provisions in place do not take into account crew safety. Security grille fitted to access door open from steering gear from to upper deck padlocked in closed positions. A key to padlock not available on inside.
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
 Fleet alert to be sent to all vessels for their checking and awareness. Incorrect arrangement of access door locking device to be reported for review and corrections.
 Company’s SI to verify closely the submitted verification reports & photos of access door securing arrangement from all vessels in the fleet.
 To verify actual condition during next vessel inspections, audits and visits by Company’s SI’s.

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
Immediate Cause
➢ Inspector observed that the jack knife was stored inside a container bin in the lifeboat and deemed not as per LSA Code 4.4.8.22.
Basic Cause
➢ Weekly checks LSA and FFA had been conducted, however, PIC was unaware of the correct storage of the jack knife as per LSA Code.
➢ Inadequate awareness of provision stated in LSA Code 4.4.8.22, stating, “a jack-knife to be kept attached to the boat by a lanyard”.
➢ Safety officer had performed random checks of lifeboat but missed out to check that jack knife was stored inside a container.
Root Cause
➢ Inadequate compliance to a provision stated in LSA Code 4.4.8.22.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN: ➢ Jack knife was taken out of the storage bin and stored inside the lifeboat where it is easily accessible. It was attached to the lifeboat by a lanyard as per LSA Code regulation. This was done at the time the observation was raised.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Lifeboat inventory - Lifeboat jack knife observed stored in container bin in storage. To be rectified as per LSA Code.
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
➢ A Fleet Alert is to be circulated to all vessels in the fleet to avoid reoccurrence of this observation.
➢ Briefed and trained all crew regarding lifeboat equipment, their location, quantity, and use.
➢ Deputy was instructed to review the provisions stated in LSA Code 4.4.8 and check if the vessel’s lifeboat equipment is in compliance with the regulation. Same must be verified by Safety Officer.
➢ Checking of lifeboat equipment to be included in the vessel’s PSC consolidated checklist sent to the office for verification prior arrival port.

AREA_OF_CONCERN: Ch X/ Engine & Steering Compartment- (Machinery status)
CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
Immediate Cause
The CBA indicates that the seafarers can stay onboard not more than 10 months. However, as per POEA contract it states not more than 11 months.
Basic Cause
Company committed to replace crew as per SEA, to the vessel’s trading pattern (tramping) and restrictions in some ports making crew change plan challenging.
Root Cause Inadequate compliance with previous Fleet Alert 26-2022 Subject: Mia LR PSC inspection at Ghent, Belgium
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN: Sought advice from POEA experts and submitted to PSCO and was accepted.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Diesel generator no. 1 and 2 exhaust high temperature alarms found changed to outside of manufacturer's instructions - 600 to 660 deg C
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
➢ To thoroughly review crew contracts to ensure it is coinciding with the CBA terms & conditions
➢ To be guided by Fleet Alert 26-2022 Mia LR PSC inspection at Ghent, Belgium.

AREA_OF_CONCERN: Ch X/ Engine & Steering Compartment- (Machinery status)
CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
Basic Cause
 In-adequate work standard and engineering practice by the PIC.
PIC did not close the drain valve of Aux GE No.1 & 2 FO leak alarm after carrying out test. Enabling the drain valve in open position will disable the FO leak alarm. FO leak alarm drain valve is normally in closed position to activate the alarm if fuel leakage is trap/accumulated.
Immediate Cause –
 Substandard act/practice for making the safety device inoperable.
 Mis-use / in-correct use of Aux. GE No.1 & 2 FO leak alarm safety device.
 Failure to follow correct procedure in keeping the drain valve closed after carrying out Aux GE FO Leak alarm test.
 In adequate supervision and failure to monitor/react/correct by senior officers.
Root Cause
 In adequate system in marking all drain valve for FO Leak alarm box to be in CLOSED POSITION only.
 In adequate compliance with the correct procedure of carrying out test for GE FO Leak alarm.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
 Immediately closed the drain valve of Aux GE No.1 & 2 FO Leak alarm box to enable alarm in case FO will leak.
 Advice PIC to stencil or put label near the drain valve “FO Leak Drain Valve to be kept in CLOSED POSITION”.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Generator engines 1 and 2 - fuel oil leak-off alarms disabled. Alarm tank drain valves in open position
PSC_SUB_CATEGORY: Jacketed high pressure lines and oil leakage alarm
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
 Discuss/remind all watchkeepers regarding Technical Manual Chapter 2.3.10 Duties of Engine Room Ratings to regularly check these drain valves in close position.
 A fleet alert to be circulated to all vessels in the fleet for their guidance and awareness of this deficiency.

AREA_OF_CONCERN: Ch X/ Engine & Steering Compartment- (Machinery status)
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Bilges pump and Fire and GS pump priming system inoperative

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
Direct Cause:
. The PIC was unable to clearly explain the meaning of the abbreviations - “O”, “C” and “P” written under the Position Fixing Interval column when being asked by the PSCO.
Indirect Cause:
. The meanings of the said abbreviations were not stated in the printed passage plan. Although, this can be seen in the soft copy of the OP-01 Form under Waypoint Guidance tab.
. The PIC had presented the section in the Navigation Manual where the meaning of the abbreviations was stated. However, the PSCO recommended that these be included in the printed Passage Plan form for easy reference.
Root Cause
. Inadequate understanding of the OP-01 Passage Plan form. The Position Fixing Abbreviations and its meanings were already included in the “Waypoint Guidance” Tab which was not presented to the PSCO.
. Inadequate understanding of the Navigation Manual Chapter 12.11.36 Position Verification (ECDIS).
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
. The PIC immediately attached a print-out of the Position Fixing Interval Table to the Passage Plan and presented it to the PSCO.
. An Extraordinary Safety Meeting was conducted to brief the Bridge Team regarding the Position Fixing Interval column as outlined in the OP-01 Passage Plan form and Navigation Manual.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Voyage plan to Dalian not made as required
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
. A Fleet Alert is to be circulated to all vessels and must be discussed with all crew to avoid recurrence of similar PSC deficiencies.
. “Waypoint Guidance” as specified in the OP-01 shall be printed out and attached to every Passage Plan. This table shall be prominently displayed on the bridge and be readily available for easy reference.
. Training to be conducted to all Bridge Team members to discuss Navigation Manual Chapter 12.11.36 Position Verification (ECDIS) and guidance on the OP-01 Passage Plan form.
. Lessons from this deficiency are to be discussed with joining deck officers during their pre-joining briefing in the office.
. Superintendents to verify implementation of preventive actions during ship visits.

CAUSE_ANALYSIS: Temperature sensors to be  Checked and calibrated at regular intervals as per PMS.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN: The temperature sensor malfunctioned sometime before the inspection and was already on the agenda of the ER staff for renewal. Engine room was kept manned and manual thermometers and frequent monitoring of engine parameters were carried out and logged in the engine log book.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: The sensor of No. 1 G/E exhaust gas T/C inlet temperature malfunction.
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION: The vessel maintains spare sensor for such situations. The vessel staff replaced the faulty sensor on 27 May 24. Evidences of corrective actions attached.
ACTUAL_OWNERS: The National Shipping Co of Saudi Arabia (BAHRI)

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
Vessel staff had just completed routine maintenance in E/R machinery. On completion of the 
maintenance, securing of tools and housekeeping was in progress at the time the PSCO boarded the 
vessel. He thus observed housekeeping condition of the Engine room, the PSCO observed an oil trace 
on main engine as an oil leak. Same was rectified/cleaned in his presence and verified. 
Root Cause: 
Housekeeping failure due to hectic vessel schedule and work processes. Vessel had just completed 
ME Unit Overhaul PMS.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
Corrective Action: 
Housekeeping completed. All tools & stores / spares secured. Engine Room Cleaning Completed
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Engine room are not clean and tidy A small oil leak was found on the main engine during the inspection
PSC_CATEGORY: Working and Living Conditions - Working Conditions
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
Preventive Measures: 
Tanking a positive note of this observation, Technical superintendent held telcon briefing with vessel 
SMT to emphasize the need for proper housekeeping and maintaining a safe working environment 
during all work processes. 
This observation shall be shares with all fleet vessels for knowledge & experience sharing and to 
highlight the importance of proper housekeeping.
YARD: Shina SB Shipyard CO@Tongyoung South Korea

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
During the voyage, the accommodation A/C was functioning properly. However, after the vessel entered the Persian Gulf, the ambient temperature increased due to a summer heat wave. Consequently, the temperature inside the accommodation also increased. During the inspection, the inspector noted that the temperature inside the accommodation was not within the satisfactory level and consequently classified it as a deficiency under Code 17.
The onboard team promptly investigated and started troubleshooting as per the manufacturer’s guidelines. As part of troubleshooting, the following checks were carried out on the AC system:
1. The fan and compressor unit were checked.
2. The air filter unit was checked.
3. The fan belt was checked. Further, the makers were consulted for remote assistance with the troubleshooting.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
The vessel is equipped with an AC plant maker: USHIO REINETSU. The layout and arrangement of the AC unit are class approved. The AC unit consists of an evaporator unit, condenser unit, and compressor. The last health check of the AC unit was carried out in the dry dock in May 2024, As per the maker's guidance, the complete evaporator unit was renewed. Further, the AC system was tried out post-renewal of the evaporator unit and the AC was working satisfactorily, with the accommodation temperature within the recommended temperature range.
Company SMS requires the air conditioning system to always be maintained in good working order to ensure proper fatigue management and shipboard living conditions, in addition to maintaining positive pressure in the accommodation during cargo operations. The computerized PMS duly covers the routine checks and maintenance of the air conditioning unit, and the same was followed on board since the takeover into our technical management.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: The temperature inside accommodation is not within the satisfactory level.
PSC_CATEGORY: Working and Living Conditions - Living Conditions
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
Further to this, a service engineer attended the vessel on 09 Aug 2024 to perform health checks of the AC system to confirm the optimum operation/performance of the system. The service engineer boarded the vessel at Fujairah “C” anchorage and performed the health check of the system. The service engineer carried out cleaning of the air inlet filter and condenser unit sea water side and replaced the drier unit of the AC system. The AC system Evaporator expansion valve, compressor was checked and found in good order. The refrigerant gas was recharged by service technician. The AC system was tried out after carrying out the above repairs, and the master has confirmed that the accommodation AC is working in good condition and the temperature at the outlet of AC unit is 18 degrees
Attached please find the accommodation temperature photos during daytime along with the service technician report attendance at Fujairah anchorage.
To prevent recurrence of the observation, vessel will be advised to check the accommodation AC system thoroughly along with the temperature inside the accommodation prior to calling in hot climate regions and also to charge the system with adequate refrigerant.

NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Nil

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
During the inspection the PSCO sighted records for inspection and maintenance of LSA/FFA 
equipment and noted them to be in order. Few LSA/FFA equipment’s were tested during the rounds 
and noted them to be working satisfactory. During the rounds on the lifeboat deck the inspector
noted that that lifeboat davit was well greased. Lifeboat and life raft launching procedures were 
posted near the life boat launching area .However, the inspector noted that the operating 
procedures for the Life raft was not placed directly under the emergency light and was placed at a 
sideways distance from the emergency light and the hence he pointed out the deficiency under 
code-17.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
On being pointed out by the inspector the ship staff immediately placed a new life raft launching 
poster under the emergency light near the life raft. Same was verified by the PSCO and the deficiency 
was downgraded and the vessel was allowed to sail from port without any delays.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Operating instruction poster of Starboard side Life Raft not under Emergency Light
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
Following the deficiency, the master carried out a briefing of the ship staff re-emphasizing the 
importance of verifying condition of IMO posters and operating instructions of the LSA/FFA 
equipment’s. Operating instructions of the Lifeboat and life raft to be placed below the emergency 
light so that it is readily visible in case of an emergency. Additionally, the deficiency was also 
discussed with the safety officer on board to highlight the importance of routine safety inspection.
The deficiency has been shared with all vessels within the fleet.

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
The root cause of this deficiency can be traced back to recent painting activities undertaken by the vessel staff on the main deck. While the ship's staff diligently executed tasks such as de-rusting, primer coating, and applying the final paint coat, they inadvertently omitted the crucial step of reinstating the markings and stenciling in the affected areas. In an attempt to address this gap temporarily, handwritten markings were applied. However, the inspector observed that these handwritten markings had faded over time, rendering them unclear and illegible.
Promptly acknowledging the inspector's observation, the ship staff took immediate corrective action. They identified the areas lacking markings and promptly stenciled them to ensure compliance with safety and operational standards.
In order to prevent a recurrence of such oversights, the Master has counseled the Head of the Department. The directive is clear: verify that all essential stencils and markings are not only present but also clear and legible throughout the vessel. Furthermore, a proactive approach to deck maintenance activities has been emphasized. Specifically, planning is now directed towards ensuring that stencils and markings are completed well in advance of the vessel's arrival at any port or engagement in operations related to specific areas, equipment, or tanks.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN: This observation pertains to the absence of markings on certain areas of the main deck, including flaps, lines, pipes, and handles on winches. Notably, the name and purpose markings, specifically those for winches' heeling/slewing, were found to be missing.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Found a lot of flaps/lines, pipes, handles on winches, name/purpose markings missing. For example winches hieuwing/slewing not marked.
PSC_CATEGORY: Health protection, medical care, social security
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION: To disseminate this learning and enhance fleet-wide compliance, the deficiency has been circulated to all fleet vessels. This collective effort aims to establish a comprehensive standard for the meticulous upkeep of markings and stencils, promoting safety and operational efficiency across the fleet
YARD: Shina SB Yard Co. Ltd. Tong Yeong,South Korea

CAUSE_ANALYSIS: After the observation was noted, the Electrician was immediately alerted, upon investigation it was confirmed that the bulb for the Emergency lights fused. After completion of the cargo operations and after disconnection of cargo hose and securing of manifold, the Master discussed with the terminal representative regarding changing the fused bulb in the non-hazardous zone on the vessel. After carrying out due risk assessment and obtaining permission from the terminal, with the required electrical work permit in place, the fused bulb was replaced prior departure from berth. The Master confirmed that all emergency lights and ordinary lights of accommodation are in operational condition.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
As per company procedures, all lights on deck, Engine Room and other service spaces, including the Emergency lights, are tested and inspected every week and prior arrival port. The onboard team had confirmed all deck lights were checked prior to calling Aqaba port and were found working satisfactory.
During the inspection, at the inspector's request, all ordinary and emergency deck lights were switched ON. However, it was observed that a few bulbs in the emergency lights were not functioning. This was verified by the inspector and noted in the observation. The inspector did note that the other light bulbs in the same locations were working satisfactorily at that time.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY:
Several of emergency lights on deck
inoperative
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION: To prevent recurrence, the Master has carried out special briefing and all crew have been instructed to carry out thorough checks of all lights onboard prior arrival port and to report any faulty light to the concerned officer for replacement. The onboard team maintains sufficient spare bulbs for flood lights at all times. The observation shall be shared with other fleet vessels.

Nil findings

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
As per Company’s Navigation Checklist “Arrival checklist for Port/ Anchor/ Navigation Special Area (OP- 09B)” all Navigation lights, Shapes, Flags and Sound Signals should be checked and tested before arrival at any port. As per Company’s Navigation Manual Chapter 11.13, OOW must be aware of the Procedures for testing Navigation lights, alarms, light controller panel and actions in event of failure. Procedures for the test must be displayed on the bridge, which the Inspector also verified during his Bridge rounds. Before arrival at the port of Inspection, the onboard team tested all Navigational lights on 28-Nov-2023 and found all lights to be working satisfactorily.
During Inspection, the Inspector requested to switch ON all Navigation lights, and it was noted that the forward masthead light (Lower) was not working. The Inspector noted this and recorded it as an observation. The Inspector also verified other Navigation lights during the Inspection, which were found to be working satisfactorily. As the vessel was loading Phosphoric Acid, rectification was not possible at the terminal during cargo operation. After completion of cargo operation and before departure port, the onboard team conducted a Risk assessment, and the required Work Permits were complied with before investigating the cause for failure of the light. The cause of non-functional light was found to be a fused bulb. The fused bulb was replaced with a spare, and the Lower forward mast head light was made operational again. Master has confirmed all Navigational lights are working satisfactorily.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN: The Company’s Planned Maintenance System covers routine testing of Navigation lights to ensure their availability for the intended use. The PMS routines cover testing of Navigation light Lamp failure alarm and Navigation light Main power supply failure alarm on a quarterly routine basis. The last quarterly routine was carried out on 15-Nov-2023 during the takeover process and all alarms tested without any notable deficiencies.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: One of navigation Iight inoperative
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
Taking a positive note from the Observation, the Marine Superintendent of the vessel briefed Master and all the Navigating Officers regarding proper compliance of PMS and Pre- Arrival checks for Navigation Equipment’s including lights and shapes. Proper operation and thorough external examination of the Navigation lights/ Night signals, Shapes to be carried out and any defect noted to immediately be brought to the notice of the office for consultation regarding possible corrective actions.
To prevent re- recurrence, the observation has been shared with all vessels in the fleet.

NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: NA

Seafarers' Employment agreement- Found one crew member employed as deck cadet, but in possesion of a COC II/1. As per applicable CBA he has to be paid as junior officer from the date of embarkation. For the Engine cadet there is not evidence of training received onboard. No training booklet available. master stated this training booklet already has been sent ot nautical institute for review. as the training period is completed he cannot be employed as cadet anymore. Contract to be reviewed as per CBA since the date of embarkation. prove of payment of salary difference to be made available by payment slips.
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION: Deck cadet and Engine cadet to be signed off at Ghent without reliever. Difference of wages to be paid immediately and Payment slips to be sent to respective crew, ITF and PSCO by today.

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
Basic Cause
➢ Starboard Navigation light lower was found busted during AMSA inspection.
Immediate Cause
➢ Although it was found in good working condition during pre-arrival checks before berthing, it might have busted due to vibration during berthing.
➢ Failure to check by PIC after berthing.
Root Cause
➢ Inadequate compliance with Navigation Manual Chapter 11.13.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
➢ Immediately instructed PIC to renew the busted bulb with a new one and showed it to the AMSA inspector.
➢ Disseminated fleet message for guidance of managed vessels.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Starboard Navigation light (lower) - not operational
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
➢ All navigational lights must be tested every watch and confirm in good working condition at all times.
➢ To adhere with the procedures of Navigation Manual Chapter 11 – related to Bridge Equipment.

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
Port authority or the agent did not inform vessel prior arrival or after berthing, regarding 
security level 2, raised at port Baoshan due to CIIE holding in Shanghai as set by China 
Government. 
Master (Ship Security officer) did not verify in advance if there were any changes in security 
level of port prior arrival at port.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
- Master verified and confirmed with agent for the present security level 2 at port Baoshan. 
- Meeting was carried out immediately with all ship staff and the security level was raised to 
 Level 2 as per security procedures, DOS signed with terminal security facility. 
- CSO notified for the change in security level and deck log book entry was made for the 
 change in security level.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Ship security level set onbord lower than security level of port facility in Shanghai
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
Company security officer briefed master to verify security level at each contracting port 
 prior arrival, if no security information were received through agent.

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
Immediate Cause:
1. Maintenance was carried out on the centrifugal filters of AEs #1 and #3 prior to arrival at the 
load port; however, the system was not tested under load conditions. During berthing 
operations, leaks were observed from the base plate due to improper tightening.
2. A minor leak from the lube oil cooler of AE #2 was caused by a damaged seal, which upon 
investigation, was found to be improperly installed.
Root Cause:
• Failure to conduct load testing of the AEs after maintenance led to undetected issues.
• Centrifugal filter base plates of AEs #1 and #3 were not adequately tightened during 
maintenance.
• Seal installation in the lube oil cooler of AE #2 was improperly executed, leading to the leak.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
Corrective Actions:
• Tightened the centrifugal filter base plates of AEs #1 and #3 to correct specifications.
• Replaced and correctly installed the faulty seal in the lube oil cooler of AE #2.
• Conducted thorough cleaning of affected areas to remove traces of oil leakage.
• Verified the functionality of all three AEs under load conditions post-repair to ensure no 
further issues.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Generator 1,2,3 oil leakage from several parts.
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
Preventive Actions:
o Conducted training sessions for engineering crew on proper tightening procedures 
and seal installation techniques.
o Observation circulated to all vessels for information sharing and learning.
YARD: Shina SB Shipyard CO@Tongyoung South Korea

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
During the documentation checks, the PSC Inspector thoroughly examined all ship certificates and inquired about the procedure for verifying and checking the validity of e-certificates. However, the Master was unable to provide a clear explanation of the correct procedure, leading the Inspector to note this as a deficiency.
Following this, the Master promptly referred to the user manual and provided a comprehensive explanation of the procedure for verifying and checking the validity of the e-certificates. Consequently, the PSC Inspector downgraded the deficiency to code 10.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
The vessel has been constructed under the supervision of Class NK and was delivered from Asakawa shipbuilding Co. Ltd. on 29 Nov 2022.
The company has outlined clear guidelines for the use and verification of e-certificates in the Ship Management Manual, specifically in Annex-3 "Guidance for Electronic Statutory Certification". According to IMO FAL.5/Circ. 39/Rev. 2 dated 20-Apr-2016, the guidelines for the use of electronic certificates were approved. The Electronic Certificates are required to maintain validity and consistency in both format and content, safeguarded from unauthorized edits, modifications, or revisions, except those authorized by the administration. They must include a unique tracking number for verification and a printable, visible symbol confirming the source of issuance. To ensure the validity and verification of E-Certificates, each page of e-certificates is furnished with a Tracking ID and QR code. Class NK has released an e-certificate user manual, Version 4.1, to address all queries related to e-certificates. This user manual has been already circulated to all vessels flagged under Class NKK.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Master not familiar for check document and certificate.
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION: Taking a positive note from the deficiency, the Vessel Superintendent conducted a briefing for the Master and senior management of the vessel on the procedure for using and verifying e-certificates onboard, emphasizing the significance of being proficient in the verification process for ship certificates to prevent the recurrence of such deficiencies in the future.

NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Nil findings
YARD: Hyundai Samho Heavy Industries Co., Ltd.

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
The company SMS requires gangway briefing is to be carried out for all the visitors on board at the 
gangway upon boarding through a placard in the gangway box. Also, the company Visitor Log (AD 18) 
is filled up for each visitors which includes their Name, designation, Visitor Id card number, Baggage 
checks, embarkation date/time and disembarkation date and time. Further the visitors onboard are 
always escorted by the ship staff to cover any job scope pertaining to the visit. Upon departure from 
the port, the Visitor log is counterchecked by the Master for completion of all entries and receipt of 
all visitor passes and initialed after confirmation is made for the fulfillment of the all entries. 
The deficiency relates to the non filling of the disembarkation date/time of the Loading Master and 
Surveyors in last port of call Sriracha, Thailand. 
Vessel had called last port as Sriracha before calling Petchburi where PSC inspection took place. The 
Sriracha and Petchburi are very nearby ports. Vessel departed Sriracha on 21st Jan 2024 at 0824 LT 
and within 02 hours arrived at Petchburi on 21st Jan 2024 at 1042 hrs LT. 
Due to unexpected delay in completing documentation at last port Sriracha, Loading master and 
Surveyor had to disembark from the vessel in hurry. The gangway watchkeeper during their 
disembarkation, collected Visitor passes from them. As the disembarking personnel were in hurry, he 
went on to assist them for disembarkation and thought of making the entry after attending the 
disembarkation. Later on, he got busy in some other manifold work and forgot to make the entry for 
the disembarkation of the Loading Master and Surveyor. As vessel arrived in next port within 02 
hours, Master also missed on for checking the completion of all entries in visitor log due to being 
busy in maneuvering and arrival formalities.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
Immediately upon noticing of the deficiency, missing entries were completed by vessel staff. 
Thereafter, the departure port check of the visitor log was completed by Master in front of the 
inspector. Inspector verified the records after completion of entries and marked the deficiency as 
rectified under code 10.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Visitor log book did not record properly.
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
After departure from the port, Marine superintendent carried out the briefing of the Master and 
senior officer on the importance of completing all entries in visitor log in timely manner. It was also 
conveyed to verify the entries by the Duty Officers during the deck rounds. After departure from 
each port, the visitor log to be thoroughly cross checked and initialed by the Master to avoid any 
missing of the entries. 
The deficiency has been shared among the fleet vessels to avoid recurrence.

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
The hydraulic setting on the door closure
unit had become offset due to frequent
use of the door for entry and exit from
Engine room. Due to this the door was not
completely closing. The onboard team
inadverently missed out to notice the door
was not closing properly as they got busy
with pre arrival checks and berthing
maneuver. The door was noticed by the
inspector during rounds which led to PSC
deficiency.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
The hydraulic self-closing
mechanism for the door was
adjusted immediatley to ensure
proper and complete closure of
the door.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY:
The A60 firedoor leading from the corridor to
engine room is not self closing.
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
Chief Engineer carried out special briefing of all
engineer officers and ratings for the deficiency
raised. All officers and crew were expalined the
importance of proper working of self closing
device on the fire doors. All watchkeepers were
instructed to ensure all the entry/exit doors
from Engine Room are kept properly shut at all
times. To avoid recurrence, senior management
officers were instructed to strictly follow the
PMS routines on fire doors and closing devices
and to take immediate corrective action in case
of any issues noted during inspection.

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
a)	Access to cargo hold fire dampers can be made through cargo hold entry point from lashing bridge cross deck and reach the location of fire dampers. However, immediate access to the cargo hold fire dampers were bolted and unable to open in emergency.
b)	Inadequate routine maintenance. 
c)	Lack of safety inspection/supervision.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN: a)	All the bolts of the grating were removed, and access was made clear.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: The ventilation dampers of cargo hold ventilation on several cross decks of cargo holds can not be reached to close because the gratings for acces from outside are bolted down and not removable because of rust. All gratings to be freed and dampers checked for proper closure. e.g. (non exhaustive list) between bay 43/41, 35/33, 27/25, 19/17, 49/51 etc. Evidence of rectification by class/flag to be send to PSC office before departure.
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
a)	Access to the cargo hold fire damper was made clear by removing the bolts of grating.
b)	Lubrication and freeing of cargo hold fire dampers carried out as required.
c)	All cargo hold fire dampers were inspected for proper operation.
d)	Training session carried out for ship staff regarding regular inspection and maintenance to be carried out.
e)	Permanent hinge-type closure arrangement made in dry dock.

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
In accordance with Company’s SMS, Galley and its associated equipment’s are cleaned on daily basis. Weekly inspections of gally, provision stores are carried out by the senior management and safety officer and the inspections are recorded in deck logbook and official logbook. During the inspection of the galley PSC inspector pointed out that drainage cover is missing for the drain channel.
The galley crew, before the arrival, in Vancouver had carried out extensive cleaning of the flooring. During the cleaning the drainage cover for the drain channel was removed. This drainage cover was misplaced during the cleaning and the crew inadvertently missed out to notify the responsible officer. Immediately after being pointed out by the PSC inspector a plan was prepared for the on-board fabrication of drainage cover for galley drain. To correct the observation from the inspector and as per the plan vessel staff after departure from port fabricated and fitted the missing drainage cover for galley. After the fabrication and installation of the drain channel, photographic evidence was sent to the PSC inspector via email, and acknowledgment was subsequently received from the PSC inspector through email.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN: Vessel arrived in Vancouver on 14 November 2023 for loading operation. PSC inspector boarded the vessel after the berthing of vessel on 15th November2023.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY:
Galley drainage cover found missing at the time of inspection. This could 
lead to a potential slip trip and fall.
PSC_CATEGORY: Accommodation, recreational facilities, food and catering
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION: The Master has carried out a special briefing of all crew after departure from port and the importance of securing the galley equipment back in place after cleaning was explained to all crew. To avoid further recurrence the observation has been shared with all the fleet vessel.

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
Immediate Cause:
➢ During inspection, it was found by PSCO that the level of L.O. was slightly lower than the normal level.
Basic cause:
➢ PIC failed to comply follow the maker’s recommendation.
Root Cause:
➢ Inadequate Compliance to Technical Manual Chapter 3 – Planned Maintenance & Schedule.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
➢ Instructed Chief Engineer to urgently top up the L.O. in the accumulator.
➢ Informed PSCO after rectification. It was closed out.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Level of L.O in the accumulator for the rescue boat below minimum required
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
➢ Chief Engineer to check the L.O level prior arrival each port.

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
- Lack of maintenance: The ship's deck was not painted over because of a lack of 
regular maintenance and repainting. 
- Lack of awareness or training: Crew members have not been adequately trained 
to identify different color of the deck line.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
Deck line was painted with contrast color and freeboard mark was 
painted white after taking permission from agents.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: "Deck line" on port side painted over in hull color. Paint of freeboard mark damaged/removed by fender.
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
Regular Maintenance: Implement a regular maintenance schedule to inspect and 
repaint deck lines as needed. Ensure that the paint used is of high quality and 
durable, designed to withstand marine conditions. To proactively engage with local 
agents to obtain permission for painting draft marks at suitable opportunity. 
 Vessel crew monitor the condition of the draft marks during arrivals and departures. 
 Crew training carried out and trained with corrective/preventive actions for the 
deficiency, 
 Fleet alert shared with all fleet vessels regarding the deficiency to ensure deficiency 
does not exist on vessels

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
Maintenance of weather deck fittings and all load line items is integrated into the SMA. During the 
inspection, the ship staff explained that continuous maintenance was ongoing. Supplies of paint and 
tools have been delivered, and the deck maintenance plan is being closely monitored by the vessel 
superintendent, who maintains regular communication through twice-weekly con-calls and weekly 
progress reports. 
Taking a positive note from this observation, vessel superintendent has carried out a telephonic 
briefing with Shipboard Management Team, to underscore and emphasis the importance of 
maintaining all load line items in good condition. 
Root Cause: 
Continuous exposure to harsh weather conditions in Arabian sea, coupled with hectic vessel schedule 
provided limited opportunities to perform planned maintenance which contributed to the observed 
corrosion.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
Corrective Action: 
Areas identified by PSCO to be prioritized. Vessel staff have completed maintenance of the 
Ventilator, Air Pipe, Casing as pointed out by the attending PSCO.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Ventilator, Air pipe, casing poorly maintained and rusted
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
Preventive Measures: 
This observation will be shared across the fleet to emphasize the importance of proactive 
maintenance and assessment, particularly for Load Line items. Enhanced monitoring and verification 
procedures will ensure compliance with maintenance activities, promoting knowledge sharing and 
continuous improvement throughout the fleet.
YARD: Shina SB Shipyard CO@Tongyoung South Korea

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
During accommodation rounds, the inspector checked the daily temperature log of cold rooms and noted that the temperature in the cold rooms was not within the required range and classified it as a deficiency under Code 17.
Upon further investigation, it was revealed that the cold room refer unit expansion valve filter was choked which resulted in the less flow of refrigerant leading to under performance to the refer unit. The onboard team did not carry out thorough cleaning of the expansion valve filter which resulted in the meat room temperature being maintained more than -18 for past few days.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN: According to company procedures, the refrigeration system cold rooms must be inspected and maintained regularly following the company’s Planned Maintenance System. The PMS requires inspections of the refrigeration system cold rooms on a weekly, monthly, quarterly, and annual basis. According to Chapter 10A, titled "Food Hygiene and Storage," in the Health and Safety Manual, detailed guidelines on the minimum storage temperatures for various food items are provided to ensure prolonged, healthy, and hygienic provisions onboard.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Cold room temperatures are not within the required range.
PSC_CATEGORY: Working and Living Conditions - Living Conditions
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
as a preventive action, a service engineer attended the vessel to perform health checks of the refrigeration system. The service engineer boarded the vessel at Fujairah “C” anchorage on 09 August 2024 and performed the health check of the system. The service engineer carried out a thorough check of the system, which included cleaning of expansion valve and solenoid valve filters, condenser cleaning, adjustment of the meat room fan impeller, replacement of the drier filter, and charging the system with refrigerants.
The refer system was tried out after carrying out the above overhauling and the master has confirmed that the temperature in the meat room is now maintained at -18 Deg C. . Attached please find the service report and the photograph showing the temperature of the cold rooms.
Taking a positive note from the observation, the vessel superintendent briefed the master and chief engineer on the routine inspection and maintenance of cold reefer rooms according to the company’s Planned Maintenance System. Further, the ship's staff has been counselled by the technical superintendent to record the temperature of the cold rooms once the defrost cycle of the refrigeration system is over. They have also been advised to verify the cold room temperatures after the completion of the defrost cycle.



As per the maker’s instruction manual, troubleshooting was carried out jointly by ship staff and office staff, and the system was charged with refrigerant (R-404A). Upon charging the system, the cooling effect of the AC system improved, with the blower outlet temperature being 24ºC.

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
During the documentation check, the inspector examined the entries in the Garbage Record Book and noticed that the records of incineration of sludge were missing. The inspector recommended recording the operation of incinerating sludge/waste oil in the Garbage Record Book and highlighted it as a deficiency. Additionally, the inspector verified the entries for the incineration of papers and oily rags in the Garbage Record Book, as well as the entries for incineration of sludge/waste oil in the Oil Record Book (Part- I), which were found to be in order. Furthermore, the company's Environmental Compliance Officer conducts monthly checks and verifications of entries in the Oil Record Book, Cargo Record Book, Ballast Water Record Book, and Garbage Record Book. The last monthly verification resulted with no negative comments, and all entries were found to be in order.
Considering all these verification checks, the PSC Inspector downgraded the deficiency to code 10.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN: In accordance with Chapter 3 “Control of Waste Generation and Management of Waste” from Environment Energy Management System (EEMS) Manual, all incineration of waste oil should be recorded in the Oil Record Book (Part- I) and signed by the person in charge of the operation. Any type of garbage incinerated must be recorded in the Garbage Record Book and signed by the person in charge of the incineration operation.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Not record incinerator operation on garbage record book.
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
The Master conducted a briefing with the Chief Officer and Chief Engineer of the vessel, emphasizing the importance of following the guidelines outlined in Annex-3 of the EEMS Manual for accurate entries in the Oil Record Book (Part- I and II), Cargo Record Book, Ballast Record Book, and Garbage Record Book.
The deficiency was shared with all vessels in the fleet to emphasize the importance of guidelines of correct entries in record books to prevent recurrence.

NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: NIL

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
The vessel is equipped with a BWTS (HMT-800 and HMT-300). During her discharge operation at Rotterdam, the vessel's crew observed a malfunction in the BWTS plant, with a "TRO status purge alarm and EUT temperature lower than ‘0’ alarm displayed along with salinity lower than 0.8 PSU. 
After investigating and troubleshooting it was concluded that the salinity and temperature alarms were due to temperature and fresh water at the berth. 
For the TRO status alarm in coordination with the manufacturers, it was decided that a technician from the manufacturer would need to attend the vessel in Rotterdam to rectify the system.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
-	The vessel's flag administration was immediately notified about the malfunction. As the IBWMC "Ballast Water Exchange" is considered an acceptable contingency measure in case of BWTS treatment failure, the flag administration issued a dispensation for the malfunctioning BWTS.

-	A risk assessment was carried out for this situation, as the vessel had to complete the discharge operation a one-time waiver was obtained to bypass the system and conduct a ballast water exchange after the vessel departure through the BWTS.

-	A service technician attended the vessel in Rotterdam on January 20, 2024, and rectified the issues attached service records. The issue was rectified upon the supply of needed spares, and BWTS was completely operational. The class verified the same.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: When testing BWM system the system was directly in critical alarm and not working. Ballast water taken on board in Rotterdam was bypassed
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
-	To prevent similar oversights in the future, A briefing was conducted by the Technical Superintendent for all officers and engineers to ensure BWTS checks are carried out properly and the procedures as per BWMP are rightly followed. 
-	This observation has been shared with all fleet vessels. All vessels were asked to verify that deficiencies raised in the PSC inspection are not present on board when calling such ports, and pre arrival checks are carried out.

NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Nil findings
Nil findings

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
During a PSC inspection at Sakai, the PSC inspector identified an issue with the watchkeeping 
arrangement placard, which did not match the actual duty of the watchkeeping crew. Specifically, 
there was an error in the watchkeeping hours mentioned for AB-2.
Upon investigation, it was discovered that AB-2 had been keeping the watch from 0400-0800/1600-
2000 hours in the previous month, but his watchkeeping hours were changed to 0001-0400/1200-
1600 hours in the current month of September 2023. However, when updating the watchkeeping 
arrangement notice, the correction for AB-2's watchkeeping timings was inadvertently omitted in the 
Engine Room notice.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
It was confirmed that AB-2 had indeed been keeping the correct watches on the 0001-0400/1200-
1600 schedule. Once this issue was pointed out by the inspector, the watchkeeping timings were 
promptly corrected to reflect AB-2's actual schedule of 0001-0400/1200-1600 hours. This correction 
was made on the watchkeeping arrangement placard in the Engine Room, and notices at various 
locations were also verified to ensure the correct watchkeeping arrangement was displayed.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Watch keeping arrangement not synchronized with actual duty of watch keeping crew.
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
As a result of these actions, the inspector closed this deficiency and issued a Code 10 for the 
correction. To prevent a recurrence of such issues, the ship's staff has been briefed by the 
superintendent to ensure that accurate information is displayed on the watchkeeping notice in the 
future and information removed for a short duration to be displayed again and Senior officer to 
ensure that . Furthermore, this deficiency will be communicated to the fleet vessels for their 
awareness and information sharing
YARD: Shina SB Yard Co. Ltd. Tong Yeong,South Korea

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
Vessel has total of 5 AE’s of which 4AE’s were running in good condition. Vessle requires maximum of 3 AE’s to suffice for vessel power generation requirement.
Basis above, an out of service No.2 AE did not affect vessel safe operation and hence vessel did not report the same to Port Authority.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
Classification society was immediately informed about the situation, and a risk assessment was completed basis total power required for the vessel to operate safely.
Classification society is planned to attend the vessel at the earliest possible time to issue necessary documents for the same.

AREA_OF_CONCERN:
Cold room, cold room
cleanliness, cold room
temperature
CAUSE_ANALYSIS: The vessel is outfitted with cold chambers (meat room and fish room) for storing frozen food. The arrangement and layout of the cold chambers are class-approved. Regular inspection and maintenance of the cold chambers are carried out by the ship’s staff as per the planned maintena system and the manufacturer's guidance. Further, prior to arrival at the port of inspection, the ship’s staff had arranged the meat and fish. While arranging the meat room, the ship’s staff inadvertently stowed a few boxes near the meat room fan. Also, the defrosting cycle was not carried out by the concerned officer, which resulted in the ice formation on the evaporator coils.system and the manufacturer's guidance. Further, prior to arrival at the port of inspection, the ship’s staff had arranged the meat and fish. While arranging the meat room, the ship’s staff inadvertently stowed a few boxes near the meat room fan. Also, the defrosting cycle was not carried out by the concerned officer, which resulted in the ice formation on the evaporator coils. system and the manufacturer's guidance. Further, prior to arrival at the port of inspection, the ship’s staff had arranged the meat and fish. While arranging the meat room, the ship’s staff inadvertently stowed a few boxes near the meat room fan. Also, the defrosting cycle was not carried out by the concerned officer, which resulted in the ice formation on the evaporator coils.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN: During the accommodation rounds, the inspector checked the galley, dry provision store, and cold chambers. The galley and dry provisions were well arranged with sufficient provisions onboard. Further, the inspector checked the refrigeration plant for the vegetables, meat, and fish rooms. The cold room temperatures were in accordance with the guidance of MLC and COSWP requirements. However, the inspector observed that the evaporator coils of the meat and fish rooms were slightly iced and raised this as a deficiency.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY:
Evaporator coils in the common area of Fridge (Meat and Fish room)
found to be iced at the time of inspection.
PSC_SUB_CATEGORY:
Cold room, cold room
cleanliness, cold room
temperature
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
Corrective Action:
After being pointed out by the inspector, the defrosting of the ice was carried out by the responsible officer, and the same was witnessed by the inspector. The boxes stowed near the fan were removed. The observation was downgraded to rectified by the PSCO after completion of the corrective action.
Preventive Action:
Taking a positive note from the observation, the Marine Superintendent conducted telephonic briefing for the ship’s staff, emphasizing the importance of maintaining the cold refrigeration system in good order. Also, to increase awareness among the other fleet vessels, the observation has been shared with the fleet vessels.

NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Nil finding
Nil findings
Nil findings
M/E Rversing Cyllinder defective

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
During the port stay, there were a total of 2 Receiver’s Representatives who attended the vessel for 
the cargo operation. They were supposed to stay onboard for the entire cargo operation and monitor 
the discharge operation in shifts. The cargo representatives requested accommodation to be 
arranged on board. The Pilot Cabin was provided to the receiver’s representative during their offduty intervals. This arrangement allowed the Shore Representative to rest and recharge in between 
their demanding duties.
On the day the PSC Inspection one of the shipper Representative, who was still on duty, found 
himself in need of a separate space with an attached washroom to facilitate a change of clothes and 
provide an opportunity to refresh. Since there were no vacant cabins on the ship, the duty officer 
arranged for the shore representative to use the vessel's hospital temporarily, given the brief 
duration of the need. The duty officer failed to comply with the company procedures.
After completion of the use of the Hospital the shore representative inadvertently left his boilersuit 
in the hospital. After completion of his shift the shore personnel went back to rest in the pilot cabin.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
We confirm that the utilization of the Hospital facilities was an isolated incident. The duty officer 
decided to provide the Hospital to the cargo surveyor considering the hospital will be temporarily 
used for a brief duration.
On being pointed out by the PSCO, the steward was directed by the master to inspect the Hospital 
area, ensuring its cleanliness and orderliness. The hospital was re-arranged to ensure that the 
Hospital facilities is readily available in case required to provide medical accommodation of board.
This was sighted by the inspector and the downgraded the deficiency to code-10 and vessel allowed 
to sail without any deficiency.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: SICK BAY FOUND USING FOR VISITORS STAY (not as required)
PSC_CATEGORY: Working and Living Conditions - Living Conditions
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
a. All shore personal/visitors boarding the vessel require to stay on board prior to a designated spare 
cabin to be provided. Incase there is no spare cabin available on-board agents to be notified to make 
alternative arrangements ashore for accommodation.
b. Effective compliance with company procedure will be verified during VIR, Audits that the Hospital 
accommodation is to be used solely for medical purposes and no visitor allowed to occupy the 
hospital.
c. The observation has been sent to all vessels in the fleet to avoid recurrence.

AREA_OF_CONCERN: Ch VI/ Pollution prevention- (Record keeping – ORB, GRB, NOx, SOx, Sewage etc)
CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
Immediate Cause ➢ Volume of low Sulphur fuel oils in each tank not recorded in ORB.
Basic Cause ➢ Wrong Entry used weight equivalent (mt) Instead of Volume (m3).
➢ Lack of guidance to Manager’s Instructions (Ref No. 5 / 2019) and ORB instruction guidelines.
➢ Inadequate reminders by Company’s PIC.
➢ Inadequate training on proper handling of ORB.
Root Cause ➢ Wrong entries made. Used weight equivalent (mt) Instead of Volume (m3).
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
➢ Amended by volume of low Sulphur oils in each tank.
➢ Manager advised Master to conduct training covering the correct procedure of filling up the ORB.
➢ SI reviewed the training records & approved in ShipPalm.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: The volume of low sulphur fuel oils in each tank not recorded in ORB when fuel oil change over operation is completed on 14th Jun 2022
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
➢ Crew must review & familiarize themselves to the ORB guidelines and instructions before making entries in ORB to avoid mistakes.
➢ The company to send fleet alert to all managed vessels for their guidance of this deficiency.
➢ All joining crew to be educated and briefed about proper filling of ORB to ensure full compliance as per Manager’s Instructions (Ref No. 5 / 2019).
➢ Master to ensure training will be conducted to guide PIC on proper recording on the ORB.
➢ Training records must be reviewed & approved by SI.
➢ Company’s Previous Circulars to be reviewed by crew on board.
➢ Company’s PIC shall review ORB records i.e. submitted weekly.
➢ The SI’s to closely check the ORB entries to ensure adequacy and appropriateness.
➢ To fully adhere with the company procedures as follows:
Reference: Environment Management System (EMS) Manual.
Annex 3 – Oil Record Book Guidelines, ORB Guidelines and MI-05-2019.

AREA_OF_CONCERN: Ch X/ Engine & Steering Compartment- (Machinery status)
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: The condition of the ship and its equipment shall be maintained to conform with the provisions of the present regulations to ensure that the ship in all respects will remain fit to proceed to sea without danger to the ship or persons onboard. The pilot reported while heading inbound Delaware Bay, DE, the vessel had no controls from the bridge for the main engine due to a governor issue. An analysis must be conducted and proper repairs completed. Coast guard requires a class report to verify that the deficiency is fully rectified and that the vessel is safe to proceed
Nil findings

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
Immediate Cause
➢ Officer in charge failed to check the contents of the SOLAS Training Manual & Fire Training Manual.
Basic Cause
➢ Master & Safety Officer failed to double check the SOLAS training Manual & Fire Training Manual to make sure specific instructions for various LSA/FFA are covered in the Manual.
Root Cause
➢ Inadequate compliance to SOLAS Ch. III Reg. 35.
➢ Inadequate compliance with safety procedures as per Contingency Manual Chapter 2.1.1 Preparedness
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN: ➢ SOLAS Training manual was thoroughly reviewed by PIC and content was amended to be ship specific.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: SOLAS Training manual and fire training manual not ship specific
R_OWNERS: Kyowa Kisen Co., Ltd. (99%) & Green Spanker Shipping S.A. (1%)
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
➢ Regular review of SOLAS Training manual especially after annual services to ensure that existing SOLAS LSA/FFA is ship specific.
➢ To be verified by SI on next visit, audit or inspection.
➢ To adhere with the safety procedures of Contingency Manual Chapter 2.1.1 Preparedness.

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
The self closing arrangement fitted to galley door has been provided with hold back pins,
which could be used to hold the doors in open position.
Even though by design the hold back pins were fitted, AMSA inspector had recommended
that fire doors shall not have hold back pins, and recommended to remove the pins.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
Vessel removed the hold back pins from the door closers and now door cannot be kept open, as
required.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Self closing fire doors fitted to galley defective
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
1) Hold back pin was provided as per design, vessel had verified other fire doors for similar
arrangements and removed the hold back pins.
2) Briefed all Ship Staff on the observation and discussed close supervision to avoid
recurrence.
3) Alert sent to fleet vessel regarding PSC findings.

CAUSE_ANALYSIS: Taking positive cognizance of the deficiency, the onboard team has fabricated cover for the galley drain path, and same has been placed in the gallery. The master has confirmed that the entire drain path has been covered to prevent any trip hazard. Attached photographs for reference.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
During the rounds in the galley, the inspector checked the galley equipment and food provisions. All equipment in the galley was well arranged as per the MLC requirements, as witnessed by the inspector. However, the inspector observed that the drain path was not covered with any cover and noted this as a deficiency.
Root Cause:
The arrangement and layout of galley and its equipment is class approved. The vessel is in compliance with the relevant requirements of MLC section 3.2. Regular cleaning of the galley and the floor is carried out by the galley staff on a daily and weekly basis. The galley is provided with adequate drains to facilitate easy draining of water. As per the ship’s design, the drain in the galley is provided with a channel to route water through the drain provided in each corner of the galley. The main drain is provided with a steel cover to prevent any tripping and smell resulting from the drains. The inspector advised that all drains need to be covered as they pose a tripping hazard and raised this as a deficiency.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY:
Galley drain covers along with its mesh found
missing , leading to a slip trip and fall. Master instructed to rectify deficiency within three months.
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION: To prevent recurrence a special training of safety officers has been carried out to assess the potential slipping and tripping hazard onboard and addressing the same in timely manner. Also to increase awareness among the other fleet vessels, the observation has been shared with the fleet vessels to cover all drains provided in the galley.

NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Nil findings

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
The concerned second engineer had joined vessel on 04th March 2024. As part of pre joining formalities, flag endorsement was applied before his joining and he was issued with Liberia flag endorsement on 12th March 2024.
During the course of inspection, the PSCO verified that onboard second engineer was duly certified with the Certificate Of Competency (COC) from the Government of Singapore. It was also verified that he was provided with Liberia Flag Endorsement mentioning the correct COC number. However, the flag endorsement incorrectly mentioned the COC issuing country as Government of India instead of Singapore.
PSCO during the course of inspection noticed above and raised it as deficiency under Code 16.
Upon further investigation, it was noted that the concerned department while making the application for endorsement had mistakenly entered the details of the COC issuing country as India instead of Singapore.
The concerned second engineer had joined vessel on 04th March 2024. As part of pre joining formalities, flag endorsement was applied before his joining and he was issued with Liberia flag endorsement on 12th March 2024.
During the course of inspection, the PSCO verified that onboard second engineer was duly certified with the Certificate Of Competency (COC) from the Government of Singapore. It was also verified that he was provided with Liberia Flag Endorsement mentioning the correct COC number. However, the flag endorsement incorrectly mentioned the COC issuing country as Government of India instead of Singapore.
PSCO during the course of inspection noticed above and raised it as deficiency under Code 16.
Upon further investigation, it was noted that the concerned department while making the application for endorsement had mistakenly entered the details of the COC issuing country as India instead of Singapore.
Immediately upon the noticing of the deficiency, the manning team was informed and application was made for his flag endorsement with correct details. The flag CRA was received on the same day and was immediately forwarded to the vessel & PSC inspector for record purpose. The correct CRA is valid till 10 July 2024.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
The vessel has been flagged under Liberia Flag and issued with Minimum Safe Manning document from Liberia Maritime Authority. Since delivery, the vessel has always been manned in compliance with the minimum safe manning certificate. Same had been verified from time to time and during the above PSC inspection.
This observation is related to the incorrect details of COC issuing country in Liberian flag endorsement of onboard Second Engineer.
The concerned second engineer had joined vessel on 04th March 2024. As part of pre joining formalities, flag endorsement was applied before his joining and he was issued with Liberia flag endorsement on 12th March 2024.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Extensive Corrosion,Waste and Metal diminutionon deck;Pipe Clamps, Valves, Nuts &Bolts, Supports, Graphtings, Frames, Holed Stairway Steps, electric earthing conduit line connections, ballast tanmk entrance Ladders, Navigation Lights Platforms etc.
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
Please find attached the copy of new CRA which was received form the Flag State Authorities. We confirm that the corrected flag state endorsement will be connected to the vessel immediately upon receipt.
As a preventive measure, a systematic process has been put in place to ensure that crew members will be provided with flag endorsement with correct details. The manning department and vessel personnel have been briefed to cross check the information on the flag endorsement upon issuance of same to ensure the timely correction of any shortfalls noticed.
A fleet-wide alert has been circulated to all vessels to promote awareness and adherence to these measures and to avoid recurrence.

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
Inadequate maintenance and testing routines
Hyper mist firefighting system on top of the Aux boiler was not getting activated. When the alarm was activated by
the PSC inspector, the hyper mist pump started as expected. However, the solenoid that controls the opening of the
valve locally on top of the auxiliary boiler did not operate, resulting in the water mist not being released.
On further investigation it was found that solenoid coil was short circuited
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Fixed water mist fire extinguishing system for the Boiler failed to activate during the inspection.
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
To address this issue, the solenoid was replaced with a spare solenoid available on
board. After the replacement, the system was tested and found to be working correctly. Subsequently, the entire system and activation points were tested again in the presence of the Class Surveyor, PSC inspector, and later during a
subsequent port visit, verified by a Company Representative.

AREA_OF_CONCERN: Ch X/ Engine & Steering Compartment- (Safety Management)
CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
Immediate Cause
➢ Only the area near the escape route was fastened with bolts and not the entire Engine Room area.
Basic Cause
➢ Previous deficiency was misunderstood. It was assumed that only the floor plating i.e. part of the safe escape route in ER tanktop needs to be fastened instead of entire ER spaces
➢ Inadequate Engineering as per design by Shipyard.
➢ Inadequate compliance with training on board. Although this information was provided to Crew.
Root Cause
➢ Inadequate guidance of the MLC procedure of Code of Safe Working Practices for Merchant Seafarers/ Chapter 20 Work on machinery and power system
➢ Inadequate compliance with MLC / Regulation 4.3 – Health and safety protection and accident prevention.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
➢ Fastened the Remaining Floor plates attached to the frames. Crew use counter sunk screws & bolts & nuts (bolt heads are grinded to make it is not protruding the steel plates to prevent tripping incident)
➢ Provided training to all crew on MLC/ Regulation 4.3 and COSWP for effective implementation
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Floor plating in engine room not fastened to the floor plate frames (this is a re-current deficiency)
PSC_CATEGORY: Health protection, medical care, social security
R_OWNERS: Kyowa Kisen Co., Ltd. (99%) & Green Spanker Shipping S.A. (1%)
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
➢ To share fleet alert to all vessels for compliance.
➢ To be verified by SI’s on next vessel inspection, audit and visit schedule.
➢ Thoroughly review monthly training and ensure fully compliance.

NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Nil findings

AREA_OF_CONCERN: Ch X/ Engine & Steering Compartment- (Machinery status)
CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
Direct Cause: Auxiliary Engine No. 2 can only perform at 52% load of its rated capacity.
Indirect Cause:
➢ Auxiliary Engine No. 2 can only perform at 52% load of its rated capacity due to the defective cylinder heads.
Root Cause:
➢ Mating surface of AE cylinder heads were damaged.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
➢ Engine officers in coordination with TSI, concluded that the rectification requires new spare set of cylinder heads.
➢ Flag dispensation applied and obtained. See Appendix 6
➢ Arranged complete set of AE cylinder heads at Kwangyang, South Korea. Installed / replaced with new spare AE cylinder heads.
➢ Arranged occasional survey at Kwangyang, South Korea. Load and AE performance tested at 85% KW rated capacity in the presence of Class NK surveyor and found in good working order.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Auxiliary generator No. 2 Malfunction
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
➢ Spares parts needed should be available onboard for immediate rectification.
➢ Defective spare cylinder heads will be brought ashore for shore reconditioning and prepared ready as spares.
➢ To complete the PMS jobs as per schedule and same reviewed & approved by TSI in ShipPalm.
➢ To be verified during pre-arrival PSC consolidated meeting.

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
Immediate Cause
➢ Inspector observed that the frying pans in the galley were carbonized, exposing bare metal, and in his judgement was unhygienic and not as per MLC 2006 Title 3, Reg. 3.2.
Basic Cause
➢ New frying pans as replacement have been ordered but were not delivered on time.
Root Cause ➢ Inadequate compliance to MLC 2006 Title 3, Reg. 3.2.
➢ Inadequate compliance to Health and Safety Manual Chapter 13.2 Food and Hygiene.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN: ➢ New frying pans were purchased locally and were delivered onboard.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Food personal hygiene - Frying pans in galley observed scratched, exposing bare metal, carbonised.
PSC_CATEGORY: Accommodation, recreational facilities, food and catering
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
➢ A Fleet Alert is to be circulated to all vessels in the fleet to avoid reoccurrence of this observation.
➢ Briefed all galley personnel regarding the incident and discussed the provisions under MLC 2006 Title 3, Reg. 3.2 and Health and Safety Manual Chapter 13.2 Food and Hygiene.
➢ Master to educate crew regarding pro-active reporting to emphasize that in any defect observed or that in any doubts on assessing potential issues, these must be reported to the appropriate superior for rectification.
➢ Random sanitation inspection must be done by the head of the department to identify potential hygiene issues in the galley.

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
The observation was pointed out by the
PSC inspector because the discharge
rate was not mentioned in the P&A
manual for Annex-II Cat-Y wash water.
However the vessel pumps and piping
system fitted onboard is as per the
Marpol requiremnt and duly approved
by class.
The crew was not able to explain to the
PSC inspector at the time of inspection.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
Communication with the
class initiated regarding the
subject matter to get proper
clarification from Class
regards the contents of the
P&A Manual as well as the
need to speficy maximum
discharge rate.
As per vessel's Class Society
(Class NK) the under water
discharge outlet is designed
as per the marpol Annex-II
discharge design
requirement. The
explanation by Class was
shared with the PSC
Inspector and the deficiency
was closed by the PSCO
(Closure email attached)
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY:
Maximum rate of discharge (Reg
13.2.2)through under water outlet substance
cat-Y code -F 17.1/2 cargo record book.
R_OWNERS: Tradewind Navigation S.A (1%),Reitaku Kaiun Co., Ltd.(99%)
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
As per the class communication there is no
mopdification required. Since the vessel is
outfitted with a “Baffle plate” on ship side
underwater discharge, Class confirmed that
there is no limitation of underwater discharge
rate from MARPOL Annex II point of view, and
this ship it is solely governed by the pump’s
capacity and design diameter of discharge
outlet.The vessels pumps and piping system is
already incompliance with the Marpol
regulation and same is mentioned in the ships
P&A manual.
The explanation from Class shall be shared
with other sister vessels in the fleet with a
similar P&A Manual to ensure awareness of
the requirement and explanation from Class to
avoid recurrence of similar deficiency
henceforth.
