AREA_OF_CONCERN: Ch XI/ General App & Condition-  (Structural Condition)
CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
1. Direct Cause
➢ Barge “Tracee Lynn” approached the own vessel dangerously close and was unable to maneuver and keep clear of own vessel.
2. Indirect Cause
➢ Barge did not comply with COLREG 72 rule 5, 6 and Rule 7 on “look out”, Safe speed and Risk of Collision.
➢ The anchorage area is only 0.3 NM across the channel. The channel is busy with several vessels operating in the area with limited sea room.
➢ Towing vessel handling the barge was unable to control her maneuver resulting in allision from astern and hard contact with the aft part of own vessel at anchor.
➢ OOW failed to raise the general alarm onboard to alert all crew immediately about the occurring incident. Instead, it was only brought to the attention of Master and Chief Officer.
➢ OOW failed to carry out his duty regarding unrestricted use of all equipment to utilize own vessel’s main engine to kick ahead to avoid or reduce the impact by taking a glancing blow from the barge thereby minimizing the damage to the hull plating.
3. Root Cause
➢ Inadequate compliance by OOW with the master's night order.
➢ Rule 5 of COLREG was not complied with. Vessel did not maintain proper ‘Lookout’ at anchor watch.
➢ Inadequate compliance with NM/ chapter 7.3 ANCHOR WATCHES. OOW failed to establish confirmed communication with opponent vessel.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
➢ OOW tried to attract the attention of the barge by all available means.
➢ Informed immediately to Master and Chief Officer.
➢ Area of contact by barge inspected for damages suffered.
➢ All tanks sounded for any water ingress.
➢ VDR data back-up saved.
➢ Master followed and complied with CN-04 Contingency Checklist for collision/Allisson.
➢ Notified USCG/QI.
➢ Master issued LOP to parties concerned.
➢ Occasional Survey was arranged by managers. The seaworthiness was verified by Class and repairs deferred as approved by Class.
➢ Extraordinary meeting conducted by managers with the ship’s staff emphasizing on safety of navigation and anchor watch especially in restricted and narrow channels.
➢ Master provided additional training to all bridge team.
➢ Permanent repair is to be conducted at next Dry dock.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: The condition of the Ship and its equipment shall be maintained to confirm with the provisions of the present regulations to ensure the ship in all respects will remain fit to proceed to sea without danger to the ship or persons onboard. While anchored, on 21 Aug 2022, the vessel was allided with on the stern causing visible damage to the hull near the unloaded water line.
R_OWNERS: Kyowa Kisen Co., Ltd. (99%) & Green Spanker Shipping S.A. (1%)
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
➢ Provide detailed training on NAVIGATION MANUAL/Chapter 7 Anchoring and at Anchor before anchoring. MSIs to verify on next ship visits.
➢ The learnings from this investigation to be shared with Deck Officers during pre-joining briefing.
➢ To fully adhere with Navigation Manual Chapter 7 Procedures and ensure appropriate records are accomplished as follows:
OP-09G – Preparation for Arrival at Port
OP-16 – Calculation of holding power
OP-09H – Anchor watch checklist

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
Immediate Cause
➢ 4 crew members were more than 11 months onboard without the Authorization for extension issued by flag state.
Basic Cause
➢ Manning Company failed to send an application to MPA for authorization of SEA extension for those crew who are already more than 11 months onboard.
➢ Manager reminded Manning Company to prepare necessary documentations through e-mail & telcon ahead of time but it was overlooked by the PIC from Manning Agency.
➢ Master & Managers failed to send a follow up mail afterwards to push for an application.
➢ Inadequate monitoring by Manning staff to ensure crew documents are kept up-to-date and valid.
➢ Manning company’s response to Managers inquiries were inadequate and not in prompt manner.
Root Cause
➢ Inadequate compliance with SMM Chapter 6.10 Guidelines to Manning.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
➢ MSI / TSI coordinated with Manning to submit an application to MPA for Authorization of SEA extension.
➢ Crew change was arranged at Suez Canal.
➢ Manning Company submitted Corrective Action Report.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY:
2 crew members (2/E and OS) are not in possession of a valid SEA. They have been onboard since 19-05-2021 (in excess of 12 months) without an authorization from flag state.

2 crew members (2/O and 3/O) have been onboard since 06-07 2021 (in excess of 11 months) no authorization from flag state
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
➢ To enhance open communication between Manning & Managers.
➢ Managers & Manning company to provide full support to the Master during inspection, surveys & other activities after office hours, holidays & weekends as necessary.
➢ Master shall liaise closely with Manning Agency and send follow up mails if no positive feedback is received.
➢ Managers shall send reminders to Manning 2 months prior expiration of contracts for advance preparation of crew change processes and ensuring crew documents are kept up to date & valid.
➢ To adhere with procedures of Guidance to Manning Manual and Ship Management Manual Chapter 6 – Resources and Personnel.

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
Routine maintenance of window wipers/controller was planned during port call/vessel stay at berth 
by the vessel crew as wipers movements were reported sluggish during checks. 
Status of maintenance work was conveyed to the PSC inspector during inspection. 
Prior departure port, maintenance was successfully completed and movements of all wipers were 
tested successfully.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
Three Wipers’ movements were reported sluggish during pre-arrival checks while others were working 
satisfactorily. 
Maintenance work progress on window wipers and controller was observed during the inspection by the inspector. 
Maintenance work was completed by the person in charge during the vessel’s stay in port. 
Window wipers were made operational and successfully tested under the supervision of senior officer. 
A closure message was sent to the PSC official through local agents on 13 March 2024 and acknowledgement was 
duly received. Closure communication is attached for reference. 
Vessel’s staff and PIC have been briefed with regards to routine maintenance and planning. Crew has been briefed to be vigilant during routine safety checks and report any defects for immediate 
rectification basis vessel operational conditions. 
Above observation shall be shared in company’s monthly finding list to raise awareness.

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
Overview:
The vessel’s computerized Planned Maintenance System (PMS) includes regular testing of the 
hydraulic starting unit for the Emergency Generator. On July 7th, a routine test of the unit was 
carried out, and no issues were identified. However, during the Port State Control (PSC) inspection, 
while the Emergency Generator was successfully started using the hydraulic starter, slight hydraulic 
oil seepage was observed around the shaft of the hand pump. This led to the inspector raising an 
observation.
Root Cause:
Upon investigation, the ship’s staff determined that the hydraulic oil leakage was due to normal wear 
and tear of the piston retaining seal within the hand pump unit, a component that deteriorates over 
time through regular use.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
Corrective Actions:
The following steps were taken to address the issue:
1. The hand pump unit was dismantled and thoroughly inspected.
2. The worn-out piston retaining seal was replaced with a new one from the onboard spare 
inventory.
3. A full overhaul of the hand pump was carried out to ensure no further defects.
4. The Emergency Generator was re-tested using the hydraulic starting unit, with the class 
inspector and PSCO present during the test.
5. The hydraulic starting unit was confirmed to be fully operational, with no further signs of 
leakage.
Photographs of the maintenance activities conducted have been attached for reference.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: The hydraulic starting unit have oil leaking when test start E/G by hydraulic starting unit.
PSC_SUB_CATEGORY: Emergency source of power - Emergency generator
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
Preventive Measures:
To prevent recurrence and ensure the continuous reliability of the hydraulic starting unit, the 
following preventive measures have been adopted:
1. A spare set of pistons retaining seals and other critical components for the hydraulic hand 
pump will be always kept onboard to ensure immediate replacement in case of future wear.
2. Additional training sessions have been conducted for the ship's crew, highlighting the 
importance of proactive maintenance for critical systems, especially the hydraulic starting 
unit. The crew has been instructed on the early signs of wear and tear, with emphasis on 
frequent inspections.
3. This observation has been shared with all vessels within the fleet, stressing the importance of 
regular maintenance and checks on hydraulic systems to prevent similar issues. A fleet-wide 
reminder has been issued to ensure proper handling and periodic inspection of hydraulic 
starting units and related systems.
4. The maintenance checklist for the hydraulic starting unit has been updated in the PMS to 
include more frequent checks for oil seepage and seal integrity, ensuring the longevity and 
reliability of the system.
YARD: Shina SB Shipyard CO@Tongyoung South Korea

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
The vessel was provided with total of 3 no’s life rafts. 2 number’s liferaft are having a capacity of 35 
persons each on both sides i.e Port and Starboard. 1 number liferaft having capacity of 6 persons is 
located at the forward as per SOLAS Ch III / 31.1.4. As the Hydrostatic release unit was due for expiry 
new hydrostatic release unit were supplied at the port of Inspection Tuticorin. On receipt of the HRU 
the ship staff renewed the old HRU with the new received hydro static unit. After completion of the 
renewal of the HRU the painter and HRU were connected back. However, the responsible person did 
not connect the painter line properly to the Starboard HRU unit which was noted as a deficiency
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
On being pointed out by the inspector, a requisition for new emergency call switch was placed 
by the vessel. However, as the emergency call switch with light was not available with the local 
vendors and the call switch with light could not be placed on board before departure form the 
port of inspection the PSCO provided an extension of 2 months for procurement and installation 
of the emergency call switch with light. The PSCO notified the vessel agents that the vessel was 
allowed to sail without any delays to the vessel.
A requisition was raised for the emergency call switch at the next port of Call Port Kelang and 
local vendors confirmed availability of the switch.
Meanwhile after departure from the port of inspection the vessel classification society Nippon 
Kaiji Kyokai were contacted regarding requirements for the emergency call switch with light 
inside the freezer room. The classification society advised that there was no statutory 
requirement for “Fridge Room Emergency Call switch light indication”. 
The PSCO was advised regarding the reply from Class who advised that the switch light indication 
was required as per IMO Resolution A.1021(26)- CODE ON ALERTS AND INDICATORS, 2009. The 
vessel classification was again contacted who advised that as per their understanding the 
guidance provided in IMO Resolution A.1021(26) was applicable for those alarms specified 
and listed in the same resolution and that there was no mention of requirement for freezer 
room emergency call switch to be provided with light and that vessel was in compliance with 
the statutory regulation.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: STBD SIDE LIFE RAFT FOUND STOWED IMPROPERLY (not properly stowed )
OWNER_GROUP: Tradewind Navigation S.A (1%) , Murakami Sekiyu Co., Ltd (99%)
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
a. Following the observation an email was sent to all sister vessel in the fleet regarding 
communication form class that the vessel with emergency call switch without light is in 
compliance with statutory requirement.
b. A briefing was carried out by the marine superintendent of the senior management on boar reemphasizing the importance for flowing the company’s Planned maintenance system regarding 
weekly testing refer chamber emergency call switch and operation of the Emergency door 
release system from inside the freezer rooms

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
Prior to arriving at Ningbo, the vessel was engaged on a voyage from Port Arthur, USA. The drafts and load line marks were checked by the ship’s staff before departure from Port Arthur as per the company’s procedures and reported to be legitimate. The vessel transited the Panama Canal while enroute to the discharge port in Ningbo. Due to the lock gate transit in the Panama Canal, the port side deck line mark got rubbed slightly, and the onboard team noticed this after berthing at Ningbo. The master requested the terminal to paint the deck line mark, but the request was denied.
The PSCO checked the ship's side before boarding and noticed scratches on the port side deck line. The paint of the port side deck line was old and faded and raised as deficiency. All other load line marks were clearly marked as witnessed by the PSCO.
The onboard team requested permission for maintenance of the ship's side at the next port, Zhoushan. The deck lines of the port and starboard sides were painted at Zhoushan anchorage. Attached are photographs of the newly painted deck line mark.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
The vessel is provided with multiple load lines, and it possesses certificates for all the load line markings. This observation pertains to the port side deck line mark, which has scratches and scattered rust stains.
Inspection and maintenance of ship-side markings and draft marks are part of the company’s planned maintenance system, and any damages or defects noted are captured in the computerized PMS. The ship side, draft marks, and the load lines are regularly inspected and touched upon at all available opportunities
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Port Side Deck Line Mark not Clear.
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
The vessel's Marine superintendent conducted a briefing of the senior management, emphasizing that the care and maintenance of the ship's side/draft marks/load line markings should be carried out as per the PMS. Additionally, the importance of verifying the condition of the ship's side was reiterated during inspections as per the PMS and carrying out routine maintenance at every opportunity, even if there is the slightest deterioration or fading of the load line markings.
The observation was circulated among the fleet vessels to avoid the recurrence of the same.

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
The ship's staff took immediate action, installing a new door closer from spare door closers available onboard and repairing the frayed pecking. This rectification was demonstrated to the inspector, who confirmed the correction within his report. Attached photo report as evidence. The Master confirmed that sufficient spares are carried onboard for defect rectification if required. Furthermore, all self-closing fire doors were checked and confirmed to have door closers in good working condition and intact fire retardant packing .
Upon investigation by the vessel superintendent, it was noted that during the weekly test on January 23, 2024, the ship's staff had removed the door closer for repairs as its performance had decreased. As the vessel was arriving at port, the ship's staff continued with the remaining pre-arrival preparations, and further troubleshooting was postponed until later. The onboard team inadvertently missed refitting the door closer in position, as they became preoccupied with pre-arrival preparations. In accordance with company policies, periodic checks of the fire doors are conducted as per SOLAS Chapter III Regulation 20/36, an integral part of the company's Planned Maintenance System (PMS). Monthly and weekly checks of firefighting appliances, including fire doors, are performed and recorded in the company's LSA checklist SF-26A.
As per the Health and Safety Manual Chapter 13, escape routes must be easily accessible and not obstructed, with doors that can be opened quickly from the inside. Firefighting teams should be able to access external doors forming part of an emergency escape route, and self-closing fire doors should function properly. Emergency lighting in enclosed trunks should be maintained, and doors should be kept unlocked or have a rapid means of opening from the inside.
While the requirements for fire doors are not explicitly outlined in our Safety Management System (SMS), it is generally expected that fire doors meet the following criteria:
•
Material: Fire doors should be made of a material that can withstand high temperatures, such as steel.
•
Inspection: Regular inspections should be carried out to ensure fire doors are in good condition and function correctly.
•
Accessibility: They should be easily operable and accessible to all crew members.
•
Resistance: Fire doors should be able to prevent the spread of fire and smoke for a specific time period, usually expressed in terms of fire resistance duration.
•
Installation: Fire doors should be installed in key areas where there is a high risk of fire, such as engine rooms, galleys, etc.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
The vessel was delivered on June 29, 2018, from JMU Maizuru Shipyard in Japan under the supervision of the classification society NKK.
During the inspection, the PSCO examined fire safety items within accommodation spaces and their maintenance records. The inspector observed that all firefighting appliances onboard were well maintained, and records of maintenance were updated in the onboard computer-based PMS system (Ship Palm). While conducting rounds in the Galley, the inspector noted that hygiene conditions were well maintained, along with firefighting and medical items. The inspector also verified that all fire doors were in the closed state, and IMO symbols indicating that the doors should be kept closed were clearly displayed. While inspecting the self-closing mechanism, the inspector observed that the fire door (A-0) from the Galley to the officer’s pantry lacked a self-door closer, and approximately 1 inch of the fire-retardant packing of the same door was slightly frayed. Upon identifying this defect, the PSCO raised it as a deficiency.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: A class fire door self-closing tool missing and fire protection material detached.
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
As a long-term preventive measure, a telephonic briefing was conducted by the technical superintendent of the vessel, reiterating the company's technical and safety management manual procedures. It was emphasized that the self-closing device of all fire doors should always be kept functional, automatically closing when released. The safety officer in charge was instructed to examine the self-closing device during safety rounds, reporting or repairing any concerns promptly.
The Master conducted a briefing for all ship staff, highlighting:
•
In addition to the regular tests/inspections carried out by the concerned officer, the crew members were counseled to report any lapses promptly.
•
All fire doors are to be rechecked for self-closing whenever any adjustment is made to the Air-Con pressure and recirculation system to ensure that the doors are closing positively. A notice to this effect is to be posted near the Aircon unit. Given the seriousness of the deficiency, it has been circulated within the fleet vessels to ensure that such conditions are identified by any staff working at the location, and any identified issues are rectified immediately by the relevant officers in charge.

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
Upon investigation, it was discovered that the failure of the fire doors to close automatically was due
to the vibration of the vessel during river transit prior to arrival at the port of inspection; the Port of 
Inspection was a tidal port, and frequent astern movements for a longer duration were given, which 
resulted in vibration in accommodation which in turn the wiring for the fire door relay had come 
loose. This issue compromised the functionality of the door closer, preventing them from operating 
effectively
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
According to the computerised Planned Maintenance System (PMS), all fire doors must undergo 
weekly checks. The last fire door testing was conducted on 27 January 2024. All were reported to be 
working in good condition.
During a Port State Control inspection, it was noted that the self-closing fire doors in 
accommodations were not closing automatically in response to the fire alarm, contrary to regulatory 
requirements and safety standards
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Accommodation self-closing fire door not closing automatically in case of fire alarm.
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
Immediate corrective action was taken to rectify the issue. Crew members thoroughly inspected and 
tested the electric connections of all fire door relays. Any loose connections were promptly tightened 
to ensure proper functionality. As a result, the fire doors were observed to close completely as 
required. The PSC Inspector witnessed the proper operation of Fire doors and was given code 10 in 
the PSC Inspection report.
To prevent similar occurrences in the future, the following actions were implemented:
1. The Master conducted a comprehensive briefing for all ship staff, emphasising the 
importance of timely reporting and proactive maintenance 2. Whenever manoeuvring causes vibrations, the connections should be rechecked to confirm 
their integrity. Crew members were instructed to conduct additional checks for fire doors 
whenever excessive vibration was noted, such as during vessel astern movement or 
anchoring operations.
3. This incident will be mentioned in the master and CE Handing over the report.
4. All vessels in the fleet were informed about this observation and requested confirmation that 
the fire doors were working properly.
YARD: Shina SB Yard Co. Ltd. Tong Yeong,South Korea

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
a) On detailed investigation it was observed that the rescue boat hook assembly, especially the
forward base plate, had considerable corrosion.
b) PMS was implemented on board however it was inadequately followed. (Ref: Tech Manual Ch 3).
The structural condition of rescue boat hook assembly was inadequately assessed by the ship
staff by not doing a close-up inspection and hammer test. The maintenance of the base plates of
hook assembly was not carried out properly and its condition was not properly checked during
the previous rescue boat lowering drills and inspection routines.
c) Inadequate Checks for Safety Equipment as required by procedures
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Found the rescueboathook-parts in rusted condition e.g. baseplate bolted to the rescueboat deck forward is in wasted condition by corrosion.
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
a) Approved rescue boat service engineers boarded the vessel on 27th Sep 2023 and carried out an
inspection of the rescue boat. Repair scope was agreed between the service engineer and Class
surveyors.
b) Rescue boat was off-landed and taken ashore to service station. New fabricated hook assembly
including the base plates for forward and aft part of the rescue boats were installed. Complete
health checks of the rescue boat were carried out by the service engineers.
c) After completion of the repairs ashore, a load test was carried out in presence of Class Surveyor.
The rescue boat was fitted back onboard and tested by lowering/ heaving the boat in presence
of Class surveyor on 6th Oct 2023.
d) This deficiency was closed by the PSCO on 6th Oct 2023.

NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY:

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
COC already issued by classification society till Dec 2023. Risk Assessment
to be maintained along with the COC.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
Port side accommodation ladder suffered damage while at port Buenos aires
in March 2020, which was reported to Classification society. Temporary
repairs were carried out by the shore workshop team, which was reviewed by
classification society after which a Condition of class (COC) issued till Dec
2023. Permanent Repairs have been planned at dry dock before Dec 2023.

IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN: The vessel will continue strict adherence to PMS procedures, including regular checks of the SCR system and associated components. Adequate stock of replacement gaskets is now maintained onboard.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Subject to Regulation 3 of this annex, in an emission control area designated for TIER III NOx control under paragraph 6 of this regulaton (NOx  TIER III Emission control area) The operation of a marine diesel engine that is installed on a ship is prohibited when that ship is constructed on or after 01 Jan 2016 and is operated in the noth american emission control area or the united states caribbean sea emission control area. vessel reported M/E SCR is not operational.
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION: Vessel replaced the faulty soot blowing valve gaskets with new gaskets and tried out and found to be working in good order. Class surveyor attended to verify the operation and attached Class attendance report of successful verification.USCG notified of rectification prior departure and closed out the deficiency.

IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN: The company has established standard procedures, guidelines, and a planned maintenance system for the upkeep and painting of the load line and its associated markings. During the deck rounds, the PSC inspector confirmed that the port side load line and its associated markings were clearly highlighted, painted with a contrasting colour, and well maintained. However, upon inspecting the starboard side, the PSC inspector noted that while all the loading line markings and drafts were correctly marked and painted with the white contrasting colour, the deck line on the ship's side was not marked with the white contrast colour against the blue ship's side. This discrepancy resulted in an observation.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: The deck line (Star board side) not paint in contrast color with the background plate.
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION: After being pointed out by the inspector regarding the issue of painting the deck line with a white contrast colour, the vessel staff promptly notified the terminal and obtained permission to repaint the deck line with a white contrast colour. Once permission was granted, the vessel staff quickly painted the deck line with the white contrast colour against the blue ship's side. After completing the painting, the inspector verified the completed work of the deck line during the inspection

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
Vessel is outfitted with 3 hydraulic powerpacks units for running the cargo pumps and deck
machinery which are located in the engine room on the main engine platform. Inspection and
maintenance of the unit is carried out as per the company’s planned maintenance system. The Last
Three-monthly inspections of the Framo units were carried out on 1
st April -2024 and the Framo
powerpack were noted to be in order. During his rounds in the engine room the PSCO noted that the
vessel was provided with three hydraulic Framo powerpacks. He noted slight hydraulic oil leak from
the power pack pipe fitting and noted some oil accumulation in the drip tray underneath and hence
noted it as a deficiency 16ac to be rectified within 14 days. Upon further investigation it was noted the hydraulic oil was slightly leaking from the power pack unit no 1. The Power pack unit no 2 and
Unit No-3 were free of any oil leakage. Prior to arrival to the port of inspection routine maintenance
on power pack unit No-1 was carried out. During routine maintenance O-ring on the return pipe from
relief valve face was renewed. During the renewal process we suspect the ship staff incorrectly
tightened the flange causing damage to the O-ring. This caused a slight leak when the power pack
was started. The leak was not noticed during the engine room rounds.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
The observation is regarding slight hydraulic leak from the power pack piping and accumulation of
hydraulic oil noted in the drip tray provided below the powerpack. The company has clear guidance
for the care and maintenance of all engine room machineries including inspection and maintenance
of Framo power packs. In line with the manufacturers’ guidelines a routine inspection and
maintenance schedule is included in the company’s planned maintenance system. This includes
inspection and maintenance of the Framo system on a three-monthly basis as per makers guidance.
Also, During engine room rounds the power pack is checked for any leakage or abnormal sound.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: PSCO observed hydraulic power and piping and fittings active cleaning accumulating in a fabricated tray underneath.
PSC_CATEGORY: Working and Living Conditions - Working Conditions
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
3. Correction of the finding
On being pointed out by the PSCO the makers Framo were contacted and order was placed for
new O-rings. The O-Rings were connected on board on 16th April-24 prior departure from the
port of Inspection. After departure from the port of inspection enroute to Point comfort the ORings on the return pipe from relief valve face was renewed for power pack No-1 . Also as a
precautionary measure O-Rings on the common line relief valve ,No-1 power pack suction flange
face O-ring and Quad Ring was changed. After changing the O-rings and boxing back the power
pack unit No-1 the system was tried out. No leaks were notified from power pack unit 1njhcv .
The USCG was notified regarding the rectification of the Leak from power pack unit No-1. USCG
requested for Class verification for closure of the deficiency.
Class attended the vessel at Barcelona on 14th May-24 and verified closure of the deficiency.
USCG were notified regarding class attendance and verification by class. USCG has confirmed that
the deficiency has been closed out in their system.
Corrective/Preventive action based on the root cause
The attending superintendent carried out a briefing of Master and CE re-emphasizing the importance
of carrying out through checks of all machinery in engine room including Power packs. After
maintenance or renewal of any part of the machinery, The machinery must be immediately
checked/tried out for correct operation and free ok leak. A briefing of the engine staff was carried
out by the master to ensure through engine room rounds are carried out to check for any leaks and
abnormality of machinery.
4. What is the plan to monitor the effectiveness of the corrective/preventive actions?
a. The Observation has been sent to all vessel in the fleet to avoid recurrence.
b. During internal audits/Vessel inspection condition of the engine room machinery will be
checked to confirm they are being operated without any defects and free of leaks.

NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Safety management audit by the administration is required before departure of the ship .Deficiency marjed ISM is the objective evidence of a serious failure ,or lack of effectivenss of implementation of the ISM Code

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
Direct Cause:
Operation of davit used for launching liferaft was not carried out during abandonship drill as per record.
Indirect Cause:
➢ Unaware of specific SOLAS Regulations even though there is evidence of drills and trainings carried out for the operation of davit used for launching liferaft is included.
➢ Master, safety officer & office staff failed to review the drill records to confirm if all processes are covered and records are adequately maintained for emergency drills.
Root Cause:
Inadequate compliance to Contingency Manual Ch. 6.4.1
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN: ➢ An abandonship drill was conducted thereafter including familiarization of the types of liferafts and the demonstration of proper launching as described in the maker’s manual and Contingency Manual Ch. 6.4.1
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: No objective evidence to prove that operation of davits used for launching life rafts is demonstrated in the montly abandonship
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
➢ A Fleet Alert is to be circulated to all vessels to avoid recurrence of PSC observation.
➢ The Operation of Davit for Launching Liferaft to be included in Monthly Abandonship Drill.
➢ Included Drill Training Matrix the Operation of Davit for Launching Liferaft.
➢ Office staff to verify submitted Drill Records to confirm all steps described in Contingency Manual Ch. 6.4.1 are fully adhered to.

NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Nil findings
R_OWNERS: Kyowa Kisen Co. Ltd (99%) & Green Spanker Shipping S.A (1%)

AREA_OF_CONCERN: Ch X/ Engine & Steering Compartment- (Safety Management)
CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
Basic Cause
➢ Lub oil drums were found stored in Engine room space, boiler platform area during AMSA inspection.
Immediate Cause
➢ Crew overlooked the consequences of storing flammable material in the Engine room area.
Root Cause
➢ Inadequate compliance with COSWP Chapter 5.2 FIRE PRECAUTIONS / Machinery space.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
Crew were instructed to relocate all drums to steering gear room.
All Lub. Oil drums were immediately transferred to the Steering gear room and secured properly.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: 30 x 200-L lub oil drums stored in engine room boiler platform area
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
➢ Chief Engineer to discuss with engine crew for their awareness and full compliance with storage of flammable items in appropriate safe locations.
➢ COSWP Chapter 5.2 FIRE PRECAUTIONS / Machinery space should be reviewed and implemented by PIC.
➢ SI verify at the next Ship’s Visit.

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
Inadequate information regarding fireman Suit 
Vessel was supplied with new Fireman Suit , which is protective non reflective clothing 
and complying with EN 469:2005, MED 2014/90/EU. 
PSC inspector wanted further clarification from class if the supplied fireman suit was in 
compliance with the requirement for firefighting protection from radiated heat.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
Vessel Class Bureau veritas was contacted to clarify and confirm if the fireman outfit 
provided onboard is in compliance with applicable requirement. 
- Class surveyor confirmed the fireman suit is in compliance with the requirements and can 
be used for fighting fire with possibility of radiant heat.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY:
Firemans outfits onboard are close proximity clothing only and may not provide 
the wearer a sufficient thermal protection from radiated head while entering an 
enclosed space where a fir is established (e.g. the Galley; where was carried out 
the fire drill). Close proximity clothing may be freely used for boundary cooling 
or for search & rescue from enclosed spaces without a fire
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
"Deficiency shared with all vessels to verify if the fireman suits onboard are in compliance 
with the applicable requirement, proper certificate and markings on the fireman suit."

CAUSE_ANALYSIS: All the checks for emergency fire pumps including operation of emergency suction and discharge valve are well established in vessels planned maintenance system. Last test was conducted on 8th oct 2023 and reported that all operation is satisfactory. Training imparted to all engineer for proper checks and tests of valve operation of ER by visiting superintendent. They were briefed of importance of indicator lamp. During the checks they are required to check all aspects of tests including indicator lamps.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN: OPEN-CLOSE indicator lamps not indicating OPEN-CLOSE position. Defective fuse replaced in Common distribution board which supplies 24 volts’ power to remote control valve lamps (OPEN-CLOSE indicator), upon valve operation, OPEN-CLOSE indicator lamps started to indicate OPEN-CLOSE position.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Emergency fire pump suction valve found not closing in engine room(inoperative)
PSC_SUB_CATEGORY: Emergency fire pump and its pipes
R_OWNERS: Comsea S6 International Ship Pte Ltd
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION: Verification of effectiveness will be checked during the next internal audit/ vessel inspection or superintend visit.

Ballast tank no.3 starboard side - both manholes with signage of gasket leakage. Inspection hatch for ballast tank no.4 starboard side leaking.
Nil findings

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
) During investigation it was observed that there was a pin hole leak at the welding seam of the
Forepeak ballast tank air vent pipe located on the port side inside the Forecastle store. PMS was
implemented on board however it was inadequately followed. (Ref: Tech Manual Ch 3). All vents,
air pipes sounding pipes should be checked periodically as per PMS and office notified if any
concerns are observed. Hammer test should be carried out at suspected weak spots for further
examination.
b) Defect reporting as required by Company procedures was not carried out. (Ref: SMM Ch 15B).
c) Inadequate Safety officer inspection as per procedures. (Ref: HSM Ch 5 Safety Inspection and
reporting).
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: The airpipe portside of forepeaktank is leaky in the forecastle.
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
The location of leak was identified by the ship staff, and it was noted that hot work would be
required to arrest the leak in air pipe.
b) Repair scope was agreed between the Master and Class surveyors.
c) Vessel was made gas free by cleaning & ventilating all her cargo tanks. Vessel was certified Gas
free by the Port Chemist on 3rd Oct 2023.
d) Repairs were carried out by inserting a new pipe section by the ship staff. The weld seam was
tested by a Dye penetration test for any crack and the closure was verified by the Class surveyor
on 6th Oct 2023.
e) This deficiency was closed by the PSCO on 6th Oct 2023.

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
During routine rounds prior arrival, the ship's staff had already identified that the air vent on the 
poop deck for the Incinerator D.O. Tank was severely corroded, and the threads used for securing 
caps on a few sounding pipes were worn out. These defects had already been planned for 
rectification and the vessel staff was awaiting a suitable opportunity for the same.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
During routine rounds prior arrival, the ship's staff had already identified that the air vent on the 
poop deck for the Incinerator D.O. Tank was severely corroded, and the threads used for securing 
caps on a few sounding pipes were worn out. These defects had already been planned for 
rectification and the vessel staff was awaiting a suitable opportunity for the same.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Air vent on poop deck for incinerator DO tank broken/uprooted from near base.
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
After departure from the port, the vessel's staff promptly addressed these issues by taking the 
following corrective actions:
Air Vent Repair:
• Hot work was carried out to repair the broken air vent on the poop deck for the Incinerator 
D.O. Tank.
• The repair work ensured that the air vent was securely reattached to its base, preventing any 
further damage or safety hazards.
Sounding Pipes Thread Repair:
• The worn-out threads on the sounding pipes were repaired.
• The repair work included rethreading or replacing the affected components to ensure the 
integrity of the sounding pipes.
The effectiveness of the corrective actions was verified through visual inspections, functional tests, 
and safety checks. The repaired air vent and sounding pipes were closely monitored to confirm their 
continued functionality and structural integrity.
To prevent similar issues from occurring in the future, the following preventive actions have been 
implemented:
• The ship's staff has implemented a more rigorous inspection routine, including regular 
checks of critical components like air vents and sounding pipes.
• Any signs of wear, damage, or potential issues will be addressed promptly to prevent 
further deteriorationThe Sikka PSC office was informed about the closure of this observation via email, along with 
supporting evidence. On 14-Sept-2023, Sikka PSC confirmed that the closure of Deficiency has 
been updated on the database and Updated Form B sent to the vessel.
YARD: NEW TIMES SHIP BUILDING CO LTD,CHINA

YARD: Imabari Shipbuilding Co. Ltd, Saijo Shipyard

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
Immediate Cause
➢ At the time of inspection, several seafarer employment agreements are exceeding 9 months onboard
Basic Cause
➢ Crew change was planned at this port. However, for safety reasons it was arranged in 2 batches.
➢ The 2nd batch crew were in excess of 9 months contract had extension agreement up to 11 months, but it was not accepted by PSCO sighting the CBA which indicated crew cannot extend beyond 10 months.
➢ Crew change was restricted at several ports due to the COVID-19 situation.
➢ Inadequate monitoring by Manning staff to ensure crew changes are planned accordingly.
➢ Crew change was restricted at several ports due to the COVID-19 situation.
➢ Inadequate monitoring by Manning staff to ensure crew changes are planned accordingly.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
➢ Master informed manning/ manager and arranged crew change at next port Rotterdam.
➢ All crew members who exceeded 9 months employment agreements were changed at Rotterdam on 30th July 2022.
➢ Master is to liaise closely with Manager/Manning company for full support during inspection.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Several seafarers employment agreements are incorrectly extended: to total period employed onboard as per applicable CBA agreements on the ITF seafarer agreements can not exceed 10 months.
R_OWNERS: Kyowa Kisen Co., Ltd. (99%) and Green Spanker Shipping S.A. (1%)
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION:
➢ Master is to liaise closely with Manager/Manning company for full support during inspection.
➢ Managers shall send reminders to Manning, 2 months prior expiration of contracts for advance preparation of crew change
➢ To adhere with procedures of Guidance to Manning Manual and Ship Management Manual Chapter 6 – Resources and Personnel.

AREA_OF_CONCERN: Ch X/ Engine & Steering Compartment- (Safety Management)
CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
Direct Cause:
➢ Failure to monitor correct position of the Aux GE drain valve for FO leak alarm.
➢ Failure to identify correct position of the Aux GE drain valve for FO leak alarm.
Indirect Cause:
➢ Lack of knowledge on the correct position of the Aux GE drain valve for FO leak alarm.
➢ Inadequate supervision by senior officers.
Root Cause:
➢ Inadequate work standards
- Crew is unable to identify the correct operation of drain valve if either to remain closed or opened.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
➢ Immediately closed the drain valve of Aux GE No.1 FO leak alarm box to enable alarm in case FO leaks.
➢ Advised PIC to stencil or label the drain valve with “FO Leak Drain Valve to be kept in CLOSED POSITION”.
➢ An illustration of the drain valve in the correct position is posted near the valve for crew reference.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Generator engines fuel oil leak off alarms drain tanks. Drain valves in open position
PSC_SUB_CATEGORY: Jacketed high pressure lines and oil leakage alarm
SUGGESTED_CORRECTIVE_ACTION: ➢ A Fleet Alert is circulated to all vessels to avoid recurrence of PSC observation.

CAUSE_ANALYSIS:
Being a new delivered vessel, the manufacturer certificates from shipyard were stored 
separately in different file and master took some time to verify the list and provide the 
certificate to PSC officer. 
However this was not acceptable to the PSC officer and he informed master that he should 
be aware of the contents of the providing such certificates immediately during PSC 
inspection.
IMMEDIATE_ACTION_TAKEN:
Master informed PSC officer the index list of manufacturer certificate stored in the file and 
explained him the procedure of retrieving the required certificates. 
The PSC inspector accepted same and recorded Code 10 in the PSC report.
NATURE_OF_DEFICIENCY: Master not familiar for check and inspection of certificate and document
